subject: Re: Tuner Updates
body:
Hey Kyle!

This is Megan, checking in for Matt. I'm going to be helping him manage his
freelance projects now that he has a full-time gig. Are you still missing
pieces from Matt on this project that you could use help with or did you
find someone else to wrap it up? If still needed, we can get a contract for
the work and put it on his timeline. Let me know!

Best,
Megan Born



On Mon, Feb 18, 2019 at 4:12 PM Kyle Weber <contact@kylewebear.com> wrote:

> So, had a nice long talk with the client. I’ll try to do my best to
> explain everything below, if I don’t i’ll try to explain for a quick screen
> share if need be. Also attached the Matrices for the tuner again.
>
> I get why this would be confusing, as does he to a certain point. His
> whole process currently with this is a long phone call with each person
> he’s selling his services to, this turner cuts that conversation down
> “tremendously”. With that being said, the only thing that makes sense to me
> now is the Free Equipment dial being interactive as each, I’ll try to
> explain in detail below.
>
> *Free Equipment Dial*
>
> 2-in-1 Bluetooth Card Reader
> 3-in-1 Bluetooth Card Reader
> Card Terminal
> Smart Terminal
> Online Methods
> Your Point of Sale System
>
> Each dot on the knob should equal one of these. 6 in total (I know we only
> have a max of 5 per, what does adding 1 more to free equipment, or all of
> them mean?). The second table was for laying out which device goes with
> each preset option. This makes sense to me as to why this dial should be
> interactive.
>
> As for the rest of the tuner being interactive, I was able to explain to
> him why it would be confusing overall. His argument is that he thinks it
> would be weird having 1 dial be interactive, but for the rest not be
> interactive, even though each dial has various dots, and are not equal. He
> wants people to play around with this as they can answer their own
> questions by messing around with it. I know this sounds weird, but I can
> see as why he would want this. For him, it eliminates a lot steps.
>
> *The other stuff*
>
>
>    1. The information icon should have a simple popover. I figured
>    something like: https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/components/popovers/ I
>    tried to get it to work, but got nowhere.
>    2. For the free equipment, there is an image attached to each option,
>    all that needs to happen is the image changes on each option selected. You
>    can see something in place here: http://staging.keenmerchant.com/
>     Simple?
>    3. I was messing around with your code a little here and there, trying
>    to change the spacing and mess with the values. How hard is it to change
>    the spacing of each dot if need be? What if I wanted to add another, what
>    needs to happen?
>    4. How’s this all suppose to work on mobile? If it doesn’t work across
>    certain browser versions, I’ll just have to tell him so if I need to, no
>    big deal.
>
>
> My final thoughts, questions on this. I can see as to why he wants this
> shit interactive, and I’m at a hold steady with convincing him we don’t
> need it. However he may give in but at the moment he says he just needs to
> see the final product and mess around with it. I want to make it
> interactive, but at this point I just need to know how hard this may be. Is
> it something you can do once, and show me how to do the rest?
>
> Lastly, I just want to apologize for any potential confusing I might be
> bringing into this. I know there’s been a gap in time since we started
> this, and your availability is limited, I’m all down for random sessions on
> your time, but I’m also looking to getting this wrapped up ASAP in the next
> 2-3 weeks so I can get you paid and this off your plate.
>
> As always, thanks again for all of this.
>
>
>
> --
> *KYLE WEBER*
> Front End Web Dev
>
> # +1 847 767 0298
>
> On Feb 11, 2019, at 7:55 PM, Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:
>
> Hey dude,
>
> I am going to relay my understanding and try to explain why it doesn’t
> make sense:
>
> 1. Right now, the first 5 dials can only be one possible value for each
> preset. It sounds like the client wants the last dial to behave differently
> even though only one value is shown at a time. Not only is this change in
> behavior misleading, I don’t expect a single person using the site to
> understand it. We can do it, but are there mocks for these “grayed out”
> states?
>
> 2. As for every dial being interactive, what I said before about this
> being way more work than our first session still applies. Since some values
> are shared by multiple presets, the client will have to be very specific
> about which preset maps to every shared value. No matter what, this will
> still be confusing to probably everyone since it’s not a one-to-one
> relationship and some presets will never be selected even though they have
> that value.
>
> 3. Have the links and the design for the bottom button been provided?
>
> That’s all for now. Please share your thoughts.
>
> I don’t have full afternoons anymore and I am currently at capacity, so
> we’ll have to build this out in a few short random sessions.
>
>
> On Mon, Feb 11, 2019 at 12:31 PM Kyle Weber <contact@kylewebear.com>
> wrote:
>
>> Hey Matt,
>>
>> Updates from z client after I had my call with him.
>>
>> Tuner second table(from excel sheet), there are 6 dots on the free
>> equipment dial. For example if someone selects No Face to Face
>> Transactions, the only options available should be Online Methods and Your
>> Point of Sale System, the other options should grey out and still be

>>
>> And lastly, a button at the bottom of the tuner that will link to a

>>
>> Let me know if I need to clarify on any of this.

subject: Re: Tuner Updates
body:
Hey dude,

I am going to relay my understanding and try to explain why it doesn’t make
sense:

1. Right now, the first 5 dials can only be one possible value for each
preset. It sounds like the client wants the last dial to behave differently
even though only one value is shown at a time. Not only is this change in
behavior misleading, I don’t expect a single person using the site to
understand it. We can do it, but are there mocks for these “grayed out”
states?

2. As for every dial being interactive, what I said before about this being
way more work than our first session still applies. Since some values are
shared by multiple presets, the client will have to be very specific about
which preset maps to every shared value. No matter what, this will still be
confusing to probably everyone since it’s not a one-to-one relationship and
some presets will never be selected even though they have that value.

3. Have the links and the design for the bottom button been provided?

That’s all for now. Please share your thoughts.

I don’t have full afternoons anymore and I am currently at capacity, so
we’ll have to build this out in a few short random sessions.


On Mon, Feb 11, 2019 at 12:31 PM Kyle Weber <contact@kylewebear.com> wrote:

> Hey Matt,
>
> Updates from z client after I had my call with him.
>
> Tuner second table(from excel sheet), there are 6 dots on the free
> equipment dial. For example if someone selects No Face to Face
> Transactions, the only options available should be Online Methods and Your
> Point of Sale System, the other options should grey out and still be
> selected, if they change it to another Equipment option the other dials
> will change to another tuned preset.
>
> He also wanted every dial to be interactive with the same idea that if an
> option is selected and its not available the other dials will change to the
> setting that option is part of.
>
> And lastly, a button at the bottom of the tuner that will link to a
> external link that will change to where goes depending on the preset
> options.
>
> Let me know if I need to clarify on any of this.
>
> As always, thank you thank you thank you.
>
> --
> *KYLE WEBER*
> Front End Web Dev
>
> # +1 847 767 0298
>
>

subject: Re: Artemis Health: Checkin
body:
Hi Laura and Kelly!

With my current client, I am charging $100 an hour. Full-time is closer to
$65/hr if I’m not itemizing or accounting for breaks, delays, etc.

Btw, my last Cobra payment was $1,773.87 and I believe it’s the same each
month.

When is a good time to do a call?

Thank you!
Matt

Chris about the start date. We should have a clearer idea of what is best
and commit to a start date then. I’ll follow up with you after that.

Thank you!

Matt

subject: Church Flyer Design Work via myXP
body:
Hi Ricky!

Tyler told me you needed some design work. As a new church client, let’s
try this: send me all the content you want in the brochure. I’ll do a first
pass, and we’ll go from there to discuss our work agreement, feedback and
revisions, delivering printable files, and doing more work together in the
future.

Does that work for you or do you want to set up a call first?

Looking forward to working with you!

Matt

subject: Interview Follow-Up
body:
Hi Ben!

Hope you are having a great week! I was bummed to hear the news from Jon
last week, but he mentioned you were willing to do a follow-up. I would
love to take you up on that offer. When is the best time for you this week
or next?

Cheers!
Matt

body:
Thanks, Chris!

Hello again, Laura! 👋🏼

I am looking forward to connecting with you and so excited to work with the
team! Like Chris said, I started my contract work today so I will write
some notes to help determine the best timing now that I am getting a
clearer understanding of that work. Let me know if you need anything from
me ahead of next week!

Massively appreciative,
Matt

> project starting that could take 3-6 weeks at ~ 30 hrs/week, so we will

subject: Re: Configure One Web App UI Design

Re: Configure One Web App UI Design
Re: Thank you! 🙌🏼
body:
Morning, Sal!

Josh encouraged me to watch videos of Adam Neumann talking, so I’ve watched
one every day since. In a recent interview with Ashton Kutcher, they talk
about income inequality and influencing that. In his speech at the UJA
Federation last month, he talks about his spirituality and says, “there are
many different practices on this planet and we do not discriminate against
any of them.” I was raised in a religious family and was a breakout
facilitator for our Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion guild at Sprout
Social, so I’m simply curious how this is prioritized in the culture and
resources. This question is geared towards the role We’s design org plays
which hopefully would influence and strengthen initiatives like the hiring
strategy. I haven’t dug into the job portal yet so let me know if you want
me to do something specific and offer my feedback. :)

Question for you: *How important is understanding how we collectively treat
people as a for-profit company?*

Matt

subject: Fwd: Thank you! 🙌🏼
body:
I CC’d you on this message to Josh, Ben, and Allie, but typo’d your last
name! smh

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Matt Born <me@mattborn.com>
Date: Tue, Jan 22, 2019 at 12:20 PM
Subject: Thank you! 🙌🏼
To: <josh.abrams@wework.com>, <ben.fullerton@wework.com>, <
allie.strauss@wework.com>
Cc: <sal.kahn@wework.com>, Jon Grover <jon.grover@teem.com>


Happy Tuesday, Josh, Ben, and Allie!

Hope your travels back home were smooth. Thank you so much for your time
last week. It meant a lot to me to be given extra time when you were on
such a tight schedule.

While I initially thought the exercise was better-suited for a UI role, it
made sense why we focused primarily on how I articulated past decisions to
reveal my thought process. I told Sal to encourage future candidates to
have source files for *every* screen they plan to show including native to
make the most of that time. Thank you for your grace during that process!

Here are some takeaways I captured from our brief conversation:

* *WeWork was born with its values.*
** Commitment … I would work here even if I didn’t get paid.*
** Ambition … sense-making … *[and]* organizing that … *[as a]* values-driven
org.*

Statements like these affirm that being a designer for WeWork is the
opportunity of a lifetime and I look forward to your decision.

Question for next time: *As a design organization for a brand at this level
of community influence, how do we champion diversity, equity, and
inclusion?*

Massively grateful,
Matt

subject: Feedback on email to Josh, Ben, and Allie
body:
Morning Jon,

I wanted to follow up with design leadership to thank them and share some
thoughts, but I would prefer to get your feedback before I send.

Also, should I including anyone else on the CC list when I send this?

Thanks for your help!

—

Happy Tuesday, Josh, Ben, and Allie!

Hope your travels back home were smooth. Thank you so much for your time
last week. It meant a lot to me to be given extra time when you were on
such a tight schedule.

While I initially thought the exercise was better-suited for a UI role, it
made sense why we focused primarily on how I articulated past decisions to
reveal my thought process. I told Sal to encourage future candidates to
have source files for *every* screen they plan to show including native to
make the most of that time. Thank you for your grace during that process!

Here are some takeaways I captured from our brief conversation:

* *WeWork was born with its values.*
** Commitment … I would work here even if I didn’t get paid.*
** Ambition … sense-making … *[and]* organizing that … *[as a]*
values-driven org.*

Statements like these affirm that being a designer for WeWork is the
opportunity of a lifetime and I look forward to your decision.

Question for next time: *As a design organization for a brand at this level
of community influence, how do we champion diversity, equity, and
inclusion?*

Massively grateful,
Matt

—

subject: Re: Hi Adena! 👋🏼
body:
Awesome, thanks for the update!

On Sat, Jan 12, 2019 at 9:56 PM <adena@usechai.com> wrote:

> Hey Matt!
>
> The version with Open Door is now live! Feel free to update your app and
> try it out! We'll also have a desktop version in a couple weeks.
>
> Enjoy your weekend and happy talking:)
> Adena
>
> On January 7, 2019, 9:28 PM PST adena@usechai.com wrote:
>
> Hi Matt,
>
> "Virtual office hours" is exactly what we're going for!
>
> Also, the Zapier integration for Google Calendar is a great idea. It would
> be a problem if anyone ended up having their door open at an inopportune
> time, or when they were intending to work on something else. We could have
> the app ask you if you want to keep your door open or closed based on a
> pre-scheduled time slot you set (so you have the option to keep talking if
> you want to). I'll ask the team about it!
>
> Best,
> Adena
>
> On January 7, 2019, 11:25 AM PST me@mattborn.com wrote:
>
> Yes, that is what I liked most about Spoke. Like I mentioned to you
> before, the ideal state is to set “virtual office hours” that automatically
> enters and leaves this “open door” state and sends those availability
> notifications to people I work with. Perhaps a Zapier integration that
> leverages Google Calendar to trigger a change to this open door state would
> be most cost effective? I can do this manually, too, but usually I forget.
>
> On Mon, Jan 7, 2019 at 12:12 PM <adena@usechai.com> wrote:
>
> That's great to hear! And fantastic - looking forward to it!
>
> Additionally, we're creating a feature that will be ready next week called
> "Open Door". Open Door signals to your team that you're open for a drop in
> conversation. When your "Door is Open", a teammate can start talking with
> you frictionlessly and when your "Door is Closed", they cannot. It's like
> saying to your team, "I'm around for a bit to answer any questions or help
> with anything one-off". I'm curious if this would be useful to you.
>
> Thanks so much for your input!
> Adena
>
> On January 7, 2019, 11:00 AM PST me@mattborn.com wrote:
>
> Awesome, thank you!
>
> Loving the ability to have multiple teams. I’ll try to get more people in
> there and get you some better feedback.
>
> On Sat, Jan 5, 2019 at 2:39 PM Adena Bauer <adena@usechai.com> wrote:
>
> Hi Matt! Thank you so much for reaching out!
>
> I was just about to message you because our new version came out a couple
> days ago! You'll have to download a different app called *Chai*. Here are
> links to the new website <http://usechai.com/> and app download page
> <https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/chai-voice-chat-for-teams/id1447438637>. Feel
> free to keep or delete Spoke (though keep in mind, we wont be updating it).
>
> There are a few differences between Spoke and Chai. In Chai, you can have
> multiple teams and all conversations start as 1:1, and you can pull people
> in to make them group conversations. I would love to hear your thoughts the
> new version and discuss the features we're considering to add after you've
> given it a try.
>
> Happy New Year to you as well and looking forward to hear your thoughts!
>
> Best,
> Adena
>
> On Sat, Jan 5, 2019 at 9:35 AM Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:
>
> Happy New Year! 🎉

subject: Re: 🍻
body:
Happy Friday, Chris!

I am struggling to reconcile the goals you mentioned the team had for or
time together on Monday with the labeling of it as a Design Sprint. The
gist I have in my mind is “they want to see how we would iterate together
to create 2 or 3 more options.” I’ve boiled my thoughts down to a few
contextualized questions:

1. *Role and structure* - You mentioned I would both be designing and
facilitating. In a Design Sprint, the facilitator typically isn’t someone
who actively works in a design tool although I have helped create the
prototype in the past. As facilitator, I’d be responsible for guiding
people through the process, and I’m not sure how to do both unless we split
the time.

*In the past, what has the UX role looked like in exercises like these
involving the same people?*

2. *Fidelity* - You mentioned the team wanted to see my work at a level of
fidelity higher than wireframe. In Design Thinking-style workshops, I'm
used to spending most of the time without a computer using sticky notes,
pen & paper, whiteboard, etc. unless remote people are involved in which
case we’d use something like Realtimeboard. During longer design sprints,
it makes sense to spend time crafting a digital prototype, but even then it
is highly recommend to stay as lo-fi as possible.

*Is the intent of our time together to focus primarily on the last 2 phases
of a design sprint—prototype and validation?*

3. *Problem scope* - This is related to the previous two questions. You
mentioned I would be bringing something I had worked on before and deciding
the problem ahead of time. In my past experiences, I’ve tried to bring as
little information into the room as possible and lean into the process as
much as possible. As a Design Sprint participant, I believe I am strongest
in the prototype and validate phases. As a Facilitator, I’ve grown the most
helping teams diverge, converge, and organize through the map, sketch, and
decide phases.

*Could you provide more clarity on how the goals Grant, Maria, Spence, and
any others have might be served by a Design Sprint?*

*Maybe this should be less of a Design Sprint and more of a culture and
team-building exercise with less structure overall?*

I am super excited to design with the team, and I want to walk in the room
confident in the process so I can focus on listening, learning, and
actively collaborating. As I’ve been thinking through alternative formats
for the two hours, I am concerned about jumping back-and-forth between
phases which can be detrimental to the process—e.g. challenging and
revisiting the problem or solution(s) during the prototyping phase. Without
a clear process and expectations, we could slip into "design by committee"
or "design on demand" mode which could set an unfortunate precedent. I’m
sure talking through this a bit more will help me decide on a strategy.

It would probably be best to discuss this over the phone, and I hope
getting my thoughts written out is helpful for you.

Do you have time for a call today?

Thanks for your time and help!

Matt

On Wed, Dec 12, 2018 at 12:11 PM Kelly Cameron <kcameron@artemishealth.com> wrote:
Hey Matt,
Thank you for the feedback (I'll definitely pass it along) and for the questions! I floated them to Chris and here's what he said:

1.  One option to consider is reviewing the standard stories app as there are a few static visualizations in there that have not yet been added to the visualization app but have been requested to be moved in there.

2.  Users have a bit of a hard time finding something relevant for the topic they are coming in looking for such as "High Cost Claimants" or "Opioids" - it's often many steps to get from their landing page to the topic of interest

3. Probably the biggest gap here is there is not really a breadcrumb trail that takes them from the home page to the most actionable data

4. I just realized that our redesign just made it into the demo app this week, so may be better to go look at custom breakdowns (Home --> Explore --> Breakdown --> and see if there is a way to make it more intuitive to create breakdowns for users who are not super familiar with understanding breakdowns;  alternatively, taking a step back to figure out how to "find" measures and breakdowns more easily on the preceding screen to select them for an exploration is an observed gap

5. The users don't really have a strong indicator for "what action should I take", so thinking a little about how to give greater priority to more impactful areas is something we have received feedback on.

I'd also be happy to set up time to provide feedback or "act as a user" for him if that would be helpful.

Let me know if you'd like to chat with Chris about anything and I'd be happy to schedule a call with you guys. Please reach out if you have any other questions.
Thanks again,
Kelly

On Tue, Dec 11, 2018 at 3:19 PM Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:
Hi Kelly!

Just saw the invites land in my inbox and I’m in! This demo is rapidly stimulating my curiosity.

A couple things I noticed as I tried to get in:

1. The password reset likely sets the user up to fail most of the time by not stating the password requirements clearly before attempting to create a password. All the red warnings made me feel like I was doing it wrong:



2. I’m not sure if it was because I was using Safari, but the login page did not automatically take me to the dashboard. I had to manually change the URL:


Plus the loading experience was very slow on a mediocre 4G connection. It took over 30 seconds to load on my first visit and over 10 seconds to land on my second visit.

Hopefully someone can look into those things!

In the meantime, I want to get started on this exercise. One thing I need before I dig deep are a few examples of what the product team has recently learned from customers and users. Ideally, I need at least one behavioral constraint for each of the 5 areas listed previously or I’m just guessing instead of designing. Here are some ideas:

1. Perhaps a user has recently requested a recommended visualization for a certain combination of inputs that isn’t currently available or adequate? I probably won’t be able to do much with the Visualize app without an example because I am not familiar with what users are trying to accomplish.

2. Perhaps a user has voiced confusion when trying find something or a customer has requested a new major feature backed by an unmet need?

3. Perhaps a user has requested the ability to do something they cannot currently do when creating or editing stories?

4. Perhaps the team observed multiple users who don’t finish creating a custom measure after they have started and have synthesized a possible reason why?

5. Perhaps a user has requested clearer suggestions earlier in the experience explaining what they might do to resolve overspending?

Kelly, if you could float those ideas to some folks on the product team to see if they could provide additional input even if it’s “we don’t have an example like that” that would be super helpful! Otherwise, I’ll just take a shot in the dark.

Looking forward to the on-site!

Thank you!

Matt

 To help us get a sense of your design method as well as how you work with our engineering team, please take the time to redesign one of these areas of the application and bring it as a first round of review with the engineers to review in a kick off. Please feel free to reach out to us with questions and we're happy to provide support as needed.

 1. Visualize App (Home --> Visualize from hamburger menu in upper left)

 Feel free to reach out to us with any questions you have.

 https://demo.artemishealth.com/home

 Username: me@mattborn.com

 You will set up your password via the set up email.

 Thanks again,

 Kelly

subject: Pause account and refund?
body:
Hello! 👋🏼

I left my company, Sprout Social, in September which means I no longer have
access to the email tied to my Watercoolor profile and I’m not getting
reimbursed for the expense. Just figured out how to log in with my username
and had a few questions:

1. Can you change my email to me@mattborn.com?

2. Can you refund the previous 4 months since I did not login?

3. Can you pause my subscription until I get a new job that will pay for it?

Thank you for your help!

Matt

subject: Re: Hi Adena! 👋🏼
body:
Yes, that is what I liked most about Spoke. Like I mentioned to you before,
the ideal state is to set “virtual office hours” that automatically enters
and leaves this “open door” state and sends those availability
notifications to people I work with. Perhaps a Zapier integration that
leverages Google Calendar to trigger a change to this open door state would
be most cost effective? I can do this manually, too, but usually I forget.

On Mon, Jan 7, 2019 at 12:12 PM <adena@usechai.com> wrote:

> That's great to hear! And fantastic - looking forward to it!
>
> Additionally, we're creating a feature that will be ready next week called
> "Open Door". Open Door signals to your team that you're open for a drop in
> conversation. When your "Door is Open", a teammate can start talking with
> you frictionlessly and when your "Door is Closed", they cannot. It's like
> saying to your team, "I'm around for a bit to answer any questions or help
> with anything one-off". I'm curious if this would be useful to you.
>
> Thanks so much for your input!
> Adena
>
> On January 7, 2019, 11:00 AM PST me@mattborn.com wrote:
>
> Awesome, thank you!
>
> Loving the ability to have multiple teams. I’ll try to get more people in
> there and get you some better feedback.
>
> On Sat, Jan 5, 2019 at 2:39 PM Adena Bauer <adena@usechai.com> wrote:
>
> Hi Matt! Thank you so much for reaching out!
>
> I was just about to message you because our new version came out a couple
> days ago! You'll have to download a different app called *Chai*. Here are
> links to the new website <http://usechai.com/> and app download page
> <https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/chai-voice-chat-for-teams/id1447438637>. Feel
> free to keep or delete Spoke (though keep in mind, we wont be updating it).
>
> There are a few differences between Spoke and Chai. In Chai, you can have
> multiple teams and all conversations start as 1:1, and you can pull people
> in to make them group conversations. I would love to hear your thoughts the
> new version and discuss the features we're considering to add after you've
> given it a try.
>
> Happy New Year to you as well and looking forward to hear your thoughts!
>
> Best,
> Adena
>

>
> Happy New Year! 🎉
>
> Hope all is well with everything you are doing with Eleventh.
>

>
> Could you send me the details on that?
>
> Thanks!
>
> Matt
>

subject: Re: Phone Interview | Artemis Health
body:
Hi Kelly!

My voice is slowly returning to normal! We don’t get back until the evening of the 3rd, but I am open on the 4th and should be free of sickness by then. :)

Enjoy the long Christmas weekend!

Matt

Kelly

Thanks Matt, you too! Chris and Maria would like you to send your progress on the design challenge so far and ask that you don't work on it much between now and your rescheduled interview. Kelly

Thank you for making sure that login got fixed last week. I’ve been referencing the demo site the past couple days as I worked on the design task.

Houston, we have a problem. I woke up without a voice this morning! I started getting a scratchy throat and cough late yesterday and it probably wouldn’t be best for me to expose the team to that today.

Another option between now and then could be to present my design task remotely once my voice returns. Or I could just send my progress on the design task until we can reschedule.

Matt

On Wed, Dec 12, 2018 at 12:11 PM Kelly Cameron <kcameron@artemishealth.com> wrote:
Hey Matt,
Thank you for the feedback (I'll definitely pass it along) and for the questions! I floated them to Chris and here's what he said:

1.  One option to consider is reviewing the standard stories app as there are a few static visualizations in there that have not yet been added to the visualization app but have been requested to be moved in there.

2.  Users have a bit of a hard time finding something relevant for the topic they are coming in looking for such as "High Cost Claimants" or "Opioids" - it's often many steps to get from their landing page to the topic of interest

3. Probably the biggest gap here is there is not really a breadcrumb trail that takes them from the home page to the most actionable data

4. I just realized that our redesign just made it into the demo app this week, so may be better to go look at custom breakdowns (Home --> Explore --> Breakdown --> and see if there is a way to make it more intuitive to create breakdowns for users who are not super familiar with understanding breakdowns;  alternatively, taking a step back to figure out how to "find" measures and breakdowns more easily on the preceding screen to select them for an exploration is an observed gap

5. The users don't really have a strong indicator for "what action should I take", so thinking a little about how to give greater priority to more impactful areas is something we have received feedback on.

I'd also be happy to set up time to provide feedback or "act as a user" for him if that would be helpful.

Let me know if you'd like to chat with Chris about anything and I'd be happy to schedule a call with you guys. Please reach out if you have any other questions.
Thanks again,
Kelly

subject: Re: Enjoy The Journey
body:
This is awesome, thank you!

I find it personally encouraging as well. 🙂

Assuming “This is a mistake I’m bent I’m never repeating.” is supposed to
be “This is a mistake I’m bent *on* never repeating.”

What’s the next step for this again?

On Tue, Dec 18, 2018 at 4:23 PM Pastor Ryan Huguley <ryan@ridgeline.tv>
wrote:

> Article I’m working on that I referenced when we met today:
>
> Enjoy The Journey
>
> It’s been almost a decade since we started our first church, Redemption. I
> was 27 at the time and I’m still amazed at all God did and continues to do
> there. It was hard, terrifying and stressful, but rarely boring.
>
> While I’m amazed by and grateful for all God did, if I’m honest, I didn’t
> enjoy very much of it. Here’s why: The reality is, I was so consumed by
> surviving the current phase and getting on to the next, I never did a good
> job of slowing down and soaking in how special it all was. Rather than
> intentionally enjoy the amazing relationships, the health, and all the
> specific and regular ways in which God moved my eyes were far too often
> fixed down the road on the horizon.
>
> This is a mistake I’m bent I’m never repeating.
>
> Now it’s ten years later and we’ve started another church in a new city.
> It’s hard, terrifying, stressful and still not boring. But I’m enjoying
> life and ministry so much more than I did the first time around. I’ve even
> gone so far as to write this into what I call The Ridgeline Cultural Canon
> (I’ll write more on that later). One of the foundational parts of our
> culture is this:
>
> We enjoy the journey.
> We have a vision for the future, but we find joy in the present.
>
> Do we have specific goals that we want to attain? Yes.
>
> Do we have a vision for Ridgeline beyond the survival phase? Absolutely.
>
> Do we want to see more people meet and mature in Jesus? Obviously.
>
> The difference is, we refuse to buy into the lie that it is only after we
> attain those things that we will be happy.
>
> God is good right now!
>
> There is much in life that is great at this very moment!
>
> Fruitful ministry is happening every day!
>
> Here’s the truth: There is nothing in the future that will make God any
> more good than He is right now. This means I can be fully satisfied with
> life and ministry right now...and so can you.
>
> This isn’t just an issue for pastors, planters and ministry leaders. You
> may be a parent who is missing the beauty of your current life stage
> thinking about the next. You may be planning a wedding, missing all the
> great things God is doing now, because you’re so distracted with “the big
> day.” You may be climbing some corporate ladder believing the next
> promotion will make all your dreams come true. You may be a student fixated
> on graduation to the neglect of all God wants to teach you right now.
>
> Don’t get me wrong. It’s not easy. It’s a daily battle to enjoy where we
> are, rather than obsess about where we want to be, so on DATE I’ll post a
> few diagnostic questions to help. For today, take a few minutes to simply
> enjoy right where you are. There is good in it because God is in it.
>
>
> 3 Questions To Help You Enjoy The Journey
> One of the toughest things for me is enjoying the journey more than I
> worry about the destination. I wrote a bit about it on DATE. As promised,
> here are a few diagnostic questions that help me find the most joy right
> where God has me.
>
> Am I trusting that God is at work?
> If I’m filled with anxiety, fear or dread, the obvious answer is “no.”
> It’s so easy to be consumed by everything that needs to happen, or could
> happen and forget that God is at work and going to get me where He wants
> me. When I start to freak out about where the people, facilities or money
> are going to come from, I have to stop and remind myself that God is at
> work and going to accomplish what He wants. My job is to faithfully ride
> His wave. Which leads to the second question...
>
> Am I putting forth my full effort?
> We should never baptize laziness, or apathy in the misguided belief that
> God is at work so we don’t need to do anything. One reason we get anxious
> about the future is that we’re not doing the things that are necessary now
> to get us where God is leading us. I shouldn’t expected to have a healthy
> launch team if I’m not building relationships, following every lead,
> praying my guts out and training faithfully. But when I trust that God is
> at work and put forth my full effort, I can enjoy the day, pace myself and
> sleep great at night.
>
> Am I living present in today?
> This boils down to a mental discipline for me. It’s easy for me to be so
> consumed with the future that I don’t focus on today. I can forget that
> doing the right things today is what actually gets me where I need to be
> tomorrow. Remembering that frees me to enjoy today. When we first moved to
> Salt Lake I would have weeks filled with fruitful meetings and networking.
> Other weeks I would have nothing. So on those weeks I fought hard to simply
> enjoy the new city God had put us in. It didn’t produce more connections
> for me to freak about not having any in that moment, so what was the point?
>
> Spend some time today with these questions. What’s keeping you from
> enjoying where you are? There may be aspects of the future, the destination
> you’re running after that are better in some ways than where you currently
> are. BUT that doesn’t mean you can’t enjoy where you are. Don’t make the
> mistake I have in the past and miss the beauty of all God’s doing right
> where you are at this very moment.
>
> *Ryan Huguley*
> Lead Pastor
> Ridgeline Church | Ridgeline.tv <https://www.ridgeline.tv/>
>
> Twitter <https://twitter.com/ryanhuguley> | Facebook
> <https://www.facebook.com/Ryanhuguley> | Instagram
> <https://www.instagram.com/ryanhuguley/> | Blog <http://ryanhuguley.com/>
>
> Sent from my iPad
>

subject: react-pdf && react-sketchapp
body:
Hi Diego!

Love what you are doing with react-pdf. Some questions for you:

1. Did you write a new implementation of primitive components or are you
using an existing library for that? (I couldn’t find any relevant
dependencies in a quick search.)

2. Any recommendations on how to leverage react-pdf without rewriting my
components currently being used with react-sketchapp? Example:
https://github.com/mattborn/preso/blob/master/src/preso.js

Ideally, I’d like to be able to easily render to Sketch while I iterate
with live reloading, then quickly save to multi-page PDF. I can already do
this by exporting all the artboards and combining into a single PDF, but
that’s more steps! It’d be great to make this programmatic.

Thank you!

Matt

Hi Kelly!

Just saw the invites land in my inbox and I’m in! This demo is rapidly stimulating my curiosity.

A couple things I noticed as I tried to get in:

1. The password reset likely sets the user up to fail most of the time by not stating the password requirements clearly before attempting to create a password. All the red warnings made me feel like I was doing it wrong:

Plus the loading experience was very slow on a mediocre 4G connection. It took over 30 seconds to load on my first visit and over 10 seconds to land on my second visit.

Hopefully someone can look into those things!

In the meantime, I want to get started on this exercise. One thing I need before I dig deep are a few examples of what the product team has recently learned from customers and users. Ideally, I need at least one behavioral constraint for each of the 5 areas listed previously or I’m just guessing instead of designing. Here are some ideas:

1. Perhaps a user has recently requested a recommended visualization for a certain combination of inputs that isn’t currently available or adequate? I probably won’t be able to do much with the Visualize app without an example because I am not familiar with what users are trying to accomplish.

Looking forward to the on-site!

Thank you!

Matt

Oh gotcha (Sorry, I’m admittedly very out of it). I’ve met Kyle Jacobsen. I’m going to shoot Zach a text to throw in a good word.

 

From: Matt Born <me@mattborn.com>  
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2018 10:54 AM
To: Kat Campagna <Kat@searchgrouppartners.com>
Subject: RE: Referred from Angela Jackson

 

Hi Kat!

 

Oh no! I hope you feel better soon!

 

Just realized my language in the email yesterday was confusing. I already had the interview yesterday! It seemed to go well. I felt prepared and Jon who arranged the interview said it was “perfect.” The interview was with Kyle Jacobsen (product director), Morgan Williams (designer), Ingemar Wiemer (designer), and Jon Grover (new UX director).

 

I attached the deck I used in the interview. Let me know what you think and let’s connect again next week!

 

Massively grateful,

Matt

 

On December 7, 2018 at 9:36:05 AM, Kat Campagna (kat@searchgrouppartners.com) wrote:

Hi Matt,

 

That’s great! I know their Co Founder Zach Holmquist.

 

I am in the office today, but I am disgustingly sick. I don’t want to subject you to this 😊 Let me know how today goes. Who are you meeting with?

 

From: Matt Born <me@mattborn.com>  
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2018 12:32 PM
To: Kat Campagna <Kat@searchgrouppartners.com>
Subject: Re: Referred from Angela Jackson

 

Hi Kat!

 

Had a full day yesterday so can we still do tomorrow? I have an on-site at Teem at 2pm. Who did you say you knew?

 

Wish me luck!

 

Matt

 

On Tue, Dec 4, 2018 at 12:21 PM Kat Campagna <Kat@searchgrouppartners.com> wrote:

Thanks Matt! I Am going to be in the SGP office tomorrow and Friday. I’m pretty flexible to meet and continue chatting.

 

From: Matt Born <me@mattborn.com>
Date: Friday, November 30, 2018 at 6:49 PM


To: Kat Campagna <Kat@searchgrouppartners.com>
Subject: Re: Referred from Angela Jackson

 

Thank you for your time today, Kat!

 

Attached is my generic resume.

 

Here are some notes from our convo:

 

* A candidate who talks too much about growth in their first interview. I feel like I’m a person who wants to master what I do before moving on to the next thing. How do I answer the question and let them know I’m comfortable with both directions? Ambiguity.

* Designer leaving Skullcandy. $100k. Asking too little or asking too much. Utah is funky about talking about money. “I am comfortable taking a step down to $100k if it meant having a better work-life balance.” To recruiter, “Where does your ideal candidate fall, do you have a range?” To hiring manager, “This is what I made in Chicago, but I recognize Utah may be a little different. There’s so much more that goes into my decision than just the salary.” Just try to get more information. Get the story. See what they’re thinking.

* Pastor as reference. People get nervous when there is a religious person of any kind. You want to protect yourself for all protected categories. Family. Race. Religion. Being a person who shares too much can definitely hurt you. Companies would rather hire someone who doesn’t have kids. Change of scenery?

* Brainstorming session in-person or mock interview. Shoot times next week. Fridays before 2 are good for Kat. We can spend an hour together.

 

Looking forward to our next convo!

 

Matt

subject: Fwd: Following up...
body:
Jon, here’s the feedback email from Adam Tolman over at Underbelly.

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Adam Tolman <adam@underbelly.is>
Date: Wed, Nov 7, 2018 at 4:29 PM
Subject: Following up...
To: Matt Born <me@mattborn.com>


Hey Matt,

Thanks again for your patience in hearing back from Underbelly. I’m
grateful you’re not in a hurry :) This is going to be a longer email as I
wanted to share all feedback as I thought that would be beneficial for you.

*TL;DR* - The team and I like you, think you’d fit in well, and think your
deep product strategy, vision, research, validation, and development
expertise would help bolster the teams confidence in those areas – which
would be valuable. With that said, there is concern that this higher level
product thinking would take priority of simply getting the work done, as
some felt like they did not see a level of craft in interaction and visual
design that would be ideal for this position.

Going deeper...

After sharing your design exercise with the leadership team (the longer
one), and after talking with Autumn, Jeff, and Britney about their
validation sessions with you, here are some pieces of positive feedback I
wanted to share:


   - *References were great* - We liked what we heard from your references.
   It’s clear that you’ve demonstrated value to the teams you’ve worked with
   in the past, particularly in your abilities as a “unicorn”. Your depth of
   skill in web dev, bridging the gap between what's designed and what ships,
   presents a lot of obvious value, in addition to being a visionary, good
   communicator, and more.
   - *Focus on research and validation* - The whole team thought that you
   had deep and demonstrable skills in conducting research sessions and
   validating your work (shown in your design exercise). This is an area where
   the team at large is less confident and where you could add a lot of value
   to our work and process.
   - *Leading kickoffs and discovery sessions* - Your experience leading
   sprints, kickoffs, research, and validation sessions is also a huge plus,
   as that is one of the core responsibilities of this role. You have good
   soft skills and can "run a room". This is big as we need someone else on
   the team to do this.
   - *Developing product strategy* - It’s clear you care a lot about
   digging into the “why” of a project, mapping things to a vision and
   strategy, making sure that there is significant discovery done and that
   everything maps back to solving a problem. This is critical.
   - *Focus on growth* - You clearly care about learning and improving your
   craft, utilizing the best processes, methods, and tools, this is an example
   that we’d like to see set for the rest of the team.


   - *Ability to mentor* - You have experience in mentorship and like to
   work well with others. Core for this role.
   - *Culture fit* - People thought you were a cool dude and would fit in
   well… obviously important.


And some potential concerns (or opportunities for growth):


   - *Potential lack of strong craft *- Specifically craft in visual
   design, with some potential concern with interaction design. Part of this
   is likely due to you not having enough time to put together polished
   deliverables for the design exercise, but some thought they didn’t see the
   chops they’d expect at this level in other work you’ve shared.
      - *Follow up:* There are a couple ways we could solve this in the
      short term. First would be for you to share some high fidelity visual and
      interactive design work that goes into more detail than what’s shared on
      your site. Things that show focus on composition and typography (in UI
      specifically). Bonus points for sharing any motion prototypes that you’ve
      created. Another option here would be to pay you for spending a bit more
      time on the design exercise, focusing on the UI. Your call.
   - *Focus on theory/interests over work* - This is kind of implied in
   other things I’ve said, but there is concern that you may talk more about
   the ideal case, best practices, or philosophical theories of design rather
   than simply getting things done and making a quick impact. *Or* be too
   connected to what you feel is best to be objective on best next steps.
   Frankly, part of this may be the nature of the interview process, but
   overall our team seeks to prioritize work over theory/ideals, which is why
   there is *some* concern here.
      - *Follow up:* Some of this would have to come later as we have you
      work on your own client projects and provide direction on 1-2
others to see
      how things unfold.
   - *Lack of brevity* - Coming from the team and from references, there is
   concern about brevity in speech – prioritizing talk over action, and
   generally being "long-winded" when it may not be necessary. I’m not
   *totally* concerned about this, as over communication is better than
   little communication, but it is worth mentioning.
      - *Follow up:* This may just be a mindfulness thing, and am less
      concerned with this as communication is going to be core to the
success of
      the role.


Hopefully these things don’t come as a surprise and you’re grateful to get
the feedback. The follow up items I listed above are meant to be some next
steps we could take to build more confidence in those areas and ease
concerns, specifically the feedback on craft.

At this point, my gut tells me that you’d be a great fit for the team and
I’d like to bring you on. That said, if we can help quell some concerns
from the team—at least in the first area—I know that the rest of the team
would be 100% on board.

Let me know what thoughts or questions you have with that. Would be happy
to discuss more in person!

Cheers.

-- 
*Adam Tolman*
Design Director <http://www.underbelly.co/>
*underbelly.is <http://www.underbelly.is/>*
C 801.599.5709

On November 29, 2018 at 2:36:39 PM, Adam Tolman (adam@underbelly.is) wrote:

Thanks for your kind words and graciousness, man. All the mad respect back at you.

Would be interested to hear what happens with those gigs. Britney, who works and Underbelly and who you met, worked at Teem. And I know a few of the folks at OC Tanner. 

Additionally, I would love to know what happens with the Reborn idea (I like the name), and would love to even be involved somehow. Having designed a few sites for our church, and redesigning one now, this is something that’s interested to me.

Lunch next week? I’m free Mon-Wed.

Adam Tolman
Design Director
underbelly.is   C 801.599.5709

On Nov 29, 2018, at 2:28 PM, Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:

Thanks, Adam!

I have nothing but mad respect for you and Underbelly. I am bummed you invested so much time and effort in this process that didn’t pan out. It means a lot that you have treated me as more of a friend than a hiring manager from day one. You have my help, support and assistance as you level up your team.

My final at bat is with an opportunity that just opened with Teem / WeWork. I also have open threads with Artemis Health and possibly OC Tanner through Nick D’Amico. No matter what, I am going to register my latest project called Reborn as a nonprofit doing design for churches using a subscription model. Would love to keep you in the loop on this! I would be extra bummed right now if this weren’t already happening.

I am wide open for coffee and lunch so the only question I have is, “when you free, yo?”

Massively grateful to you and all of Underbelly,

Matt

On November 29, 2018 at 1:56:04 PM, Adam Tolman (adam@underbelly.is) wrote:

Hey Matt,

First off, let me thank you for being flexible and patient over the last several weeks with my infrequent communication, and also for participating in a few interviews, side conversations, lunches, and texts. I’ve appreciated getting to know you more, tell you more about Underbelly, and learn about your skills and experience. You’ve been great through this whole process.

So... with all that said, we’ve decided to change our strategy on this lead designer position, focusing less on bringing in an outside hire and instead growing some internal folks on the team more intentionally – elevating them to more senior positions where they are responsible to give feedback, critique, and direction on other designers work in addition to doing work of their own. I still see a lot of value in bringing someone onboard that can shore up the teams weaknesses in product strategy, vision, dev, and helping lead discovery and research, but we may revisit that sometime in H1 2019.

There are a few reasons why this was our decision, but ultimately I feel like this is the right one, just considering the timing with our agency, clients, and projects, and what things are currently queued up for next year. Perhaps when this need resurfaces we can chat about fit.

In any case, I would love to continue to keep in touch, grab lunch, and jam on design, community, product, and church. It’d be good to keep in touch!

Again, thanks for your interest, working with us throughout this process, participating in everything, and being so open to discuss strengths and opportunities for improvement.

Happy to answer any specific questions you have!

Talk soon.

-- 
Adam Tolman
Design Director
underbelly.is     C 801.599.5709

subject: Re: Days of work in Sketch missing
body:
Thanks for getting back to me. My concern here is that while Abstract is certainly more robust than cloud storage, this is the most severe and unfortunate issue I’ve ever had managing source files. It’s unacceptable that Abstract did not include all the changes in the commit. If this is the best answer, I simply cannot feel comfortable using or recommending this as a viable product due to the huge liability it represents.

On November 27, 2018 at 7:52:54 AM, Hosam Hassan (support@goabstract.zendesk.com) wrote:

Reply above and we'll see your message.
Hi Matt,

Thank you for your patience during the holiday season. To rollback to a previous version of your file, you'd need to jump back to a previous commit.

If there was no commit previous to the one you did, there's no way to access that file. If you want me to do some more digging, I'm happy to look around your project if you add me as a viewer.

Thanks,
Hosam

Abstract

👉 We will be out of office on Thursday November 22 and Friday November 23 for Thanksgiving.

Reference our Help Center

[DOKK47-M290]

subject: Re: Thanks for your interest in GitLab
body:
Chloe, thanks for the direct answer!

Would you mind asking the hiring team for one piece of advice on what I can improve?

Thank you!

Matt

On November 28, 2018 at 8:20:09 AM, Chloe Whitestone (chloe@gitlab.com) wrote:

Hi Matt, 

Thank you for taking the time to apply and meet with our team. We've very much enjoyed getting to know you. Unfortunately, after reviewing internally, we've made the decision to not move forward with your candidacy for UX Designer at this time. We feel that you are a very talented designer, but we do not feel you are the best fit for our team at this time, and after further review with the team we unfortunately do not think that we will be able to meet you in regards to compensation.
 
We really appreciate you taking the time to get to know our team, and wish you best of luck with your current search.
 
Thanks again,
Chloe Whitestone

subject: Re: Confirmation for Onsite Interview with EIG/Bluehost
body:
Important question: Do you have coffee for me or should I stop somewhere on
the way? 🙂

On Thu, Nov 15, 2018 at 5:39 PM Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:

> Looking forward to it!
>
> On Thu, Nov 15, 2018 at 10:55 AM Lori Yunk <lori.yunk@endurance.com>
> wrote:
>
>> Hi Matt,
>>
>> We have our confirmations for tomorrow, and our final agenda all ironed
>> out for you!   Below are all the details you should need, but please ask
>> any questions!  I'll be around to make sure you're where you're supposed to
>> be during the afternoon, and to keep you comfortable.  See you then!
>>
>> You're coming to *222 South Main Street Friday 11/16 @ 8:40am.*  If you
>> can arrive at 8:30, we'll have the chance to show you around and get you
>> dialed in for your first meeting.  You're welcome to come in business
>> casual.  Please bring your computer if you plan to present anything on your
>> projects and we'll get you connected.
>>
>> *Parking and Arrival Instructions:*
>>
>> On 200 South, just before you reach Main Street, on the right/South of
>> the road is the Hotel Monaco. Pull in like you're going to valet parking at
>> the hotel, drive forward, and that is the entrance to the garage.  Select "G
>> uest Parking" upon entry.
>> Here in our underground parking garage, park anywhere Level 2 and up.
>> After you park, walk west, as each parking level has an elevator. Go to the
>> main level, this will take you to the lobby.  Check in and they'll contact
>> Heidi Naylor, our office manager, or myself, to come get you. You’ll
>> receive a visitor parking pass for the day, so you don’t have to pay for
>> parking.  Remind Heidi or I before you leave, please
>>
>> *Agenda:*
>>
>> *8:40 - 9:30 - Meet with Design team/General work history and project
>> Review*
>> Adam Delueew, Joshua Barnes, Laura Strader, Amber Evertsen, Brad
>> Griffith, Shoshana Ellis, Jenny Brown
>>
>> *9:30 - 10:20 - Project #1 Review (these will get more much more specific
>> to one project you'd like to highlight)*
>> Jenny Brown, Mike Hansen, Shoshana Ellis
>>
>> *10:20 - 10:30 BREAK*
>>
>> *10:30 - 11:20 - Project #2 Review (feel free to either cover the same
>> project as #1, or pick another project to highlight with this new group,
>> your choice)*
>> Adam Delueew, Joshua Barnes, Laura Strader, Amber Evertsen, Brad
>> Griffith, JJ Riggs
>>
>> *11:20 - 11:50 - One on One*
>> Shoshana Ellis
>>
>> *11:50 - 12:20 - One on One*

subject: Re: Lucid Software: Thanks for interviewing with us!
body:
Amie,

This is so helpful! Thank you! Super grateful to you and the team.

This feedback makes sense. I rushed my portfolio together to get on the scene and start having conversations, but it’s clear I need to do a better job presenting my 6 years of product experience. The hiring team at Instructure loved the Underbelly presentation which is why I decided to anchor on it, but I’ll need to dig deeper for a senior+ product role.

Who knows what the future holds?

See you around and thanks again!

Matt

On November 14, 2018 at 11:32:18 AM, Amie Millar (amillar@lucidchart.com) wrote:

Hey Matt - I was able to gather some feedback and wanted to share it with you. The response from the team on why we didn't move forward was because they were looking forward to reviewing some of your past work and experience. They didn't feel your experience and potential was uncovered in the Underbelly Design Challenge during the portfolio review. That project didn’t give them enough context to evaluate your skills and experience appropriately (assumptions, research, iterations, delivery, measuring success, etc). It's unfortunate you didn't have access to some of your past work, because it sounds there is a lot of rich context and experience there.

Based on this experience and what our current needs are, this wasn't the right fit for us at this time. I know the team feels you are talented and enjoyed getting to know you better. As we continue to grow, we encourage you to keep in touch and let us know if you are interested in other opportunities in the future.

Hope this helps.



On 9:54pm, Mon 11/12/18, me@mattborn.com wrote:
Sounds great, thank you!

On Mon, Nov 12, 2018 at 9:51 PM Amie Millar <amillar@lucidchart.com> wrote:
You bet. I appreciate you looking for feedback and wanting to grow from this experience.  I'll follow up with the team and get back with you as soon as I have gathered this information for you.

-Amie

On 4:23pm, Mon 11/12/18, me@mattborn.com wrote:
Hi Amie!

Thank you for the direct answer. Would you mind asking the hiring manager for 1 piece of feedback on what I can improve? Thank you!

Best,
Matt

On Fri, Nov 9, 2018 at 3:48 PM Amie Millar <amillar@lucidchart.com> wrote:
Hi Matt,
 
Thank you for taking the time to come onsite and interview with our team for the Senior User Experience Designer (Growth Team) role here at Lucid. It was great meeting you in person.

We recognize & appreciate the time you devoted to learning more about joining our team. Although you have an impressive skill set, we are sorry to inform you that you have not been selected to move forward in the hiring process. We have selected candidates whose experience & qualifications are a better match for our needs at this time.

We sincerely appreciate your interest in opportunities with us and wish you the best moving forward.

We are constantly working to create the best candidate experience possible. Below is a link to a brief survey that we would love for you to complete. We appreciate any feedback you can give us.

Survey Link
 
Best regards,
Amie

On Fri, Sep 7, 2018 at 1:53 PM Maureen Calabrese <maureen@sproutsocial.com> wrote:

Hi Matt - 

 As a follow-up to our slack, here is some additional information for you as you wrap things up.  I'll be sending your severance agreement at the beginning of next week.  As always, if you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me.

 

1. Pay & Benefits

You will receive pay through 9/7/18. Your paycheck on 9/15/18 will cover the period of 8/24/18 through 9/7/18.
Your benefits are active through 9/30/18.
As part of your severance package and in exchange for a signed release Sprout will pay for COBRA for October and November. In order to receive this benefit, you will need to actively enroll in COBRA. Within 15 days of  the end of your date of coverage on 9/30/18, you will receive enrollment materials from a company called TASC. You can enroll anytime within 60 days from your effective date and the coverage will be retroactive back to 10/1/18.
 

2. Stock Options

The ability to exercise your options expires 30 days from your departure date. 
You can choose to purchase none, some, or all of the options that you are vested in as of your departure date.'
 Please reach out to Tiffany Doyle (cc’ed) with questions or to move forward with the exercising process
 

3. Accounts

We will put all of your accounts on hold for 30 days, followed by deletion and archiving.
If you need anything (computer files, email, etc), please let me know during that time.
 

4. Contact Info

Please send any address changes to peopleops@sproutsocial.com at least through the end of this calendar year. This will ensure timely receipt of your W2 and/or other important communications related to your benefits.
 

5. Equipment Return

We will be shipping boxes with return address labels for you to be able to return your equipment.  Please be on the lookout and let us know if you need anything further.
 

6. Separation Agreement 

In exchange for signing a General Release and Separation agreement, you will be eligible to receive a severance payment of $32,728.13.  This includes your $5,000 referral bonus for Mig.
The agreement will be sent to your personal e-mail address via DocuSign.
You have 5 (five) business days from date of delivery of the document to sign and return.
If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me. We wish you the best moving forward.

 

Sincerely, 

Maureen

 

Maureen Calabrese
Chief People Officer
Sprout Social
773-304-4185
@mcalabrese312
www.sproutsocial.com
Pronouns: she, her, hers

 

Best,

Maureen

On Fri, Sep 7, 2018 at 1:53 PM Maureen Calabrese <maureen@sproutsocial.com> wrote:

Hi Matt - 

 As a follow-up to our slack, here is some additional information for you as you wrap things up.  I'll be sending your severance agreement at the beginning of next week.  As always, if you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me.

 

1. Pay & Benefits

You will receive pay through 9/7/18. Your paycheck on 9/15/18 will cover the period of 8/24/18 through 9/7/18.
Your benefits are active through 9/30/18.
As part of your severance package and in exchange for a signed release Sprout will pay for COBRA for October and November. In order to receive this benefit, you will need to actively enroll in COBRA. Within 15 days of  the end of your date of coverage on 9/30/18, you will receive enrollment materials from a company called TASC. You can enroll anytime within 60 days from your effective date and the coverage will be retroactive back to 10/1/18.
 

2. Stock Options

The ability to exercise your options expires 30 days from your departure date. 
You can choose to purchase none, some, or all of the options that you are vested in as of your departure date.'
 Please reach out to Tiffany Doyle (cc’ed) with questions or to move forward with the exercising process
 

3. Accounts

We will put all of your accounts on hold for 30 days, followed by deletion and archiving.
If you need anything (computer files, email, etc), please let me know during that time.
 

4. Contact Info

Please send any address changes to peopleops@sproutsocial.com at least through the end of this calendar year. This will ensure timely receipt of your W2 and/or other important communications related to your benefits.
 

5. Equipment Return

We will be shipping boxes with return address labels for you to be able to return your equipment.  Please be on the lookout and let us know if you need anything further.
 

6. Separation Agreement 

In exchange for signing a General Release and Separation agreement, you will be eligible to receive a severance payment of $32,728.13.  This includes your $5,000 referral bonus for Mig.
The agreement will be sent to your personal e-mail address via DocuSign.
You have 5 (five) business days from date of delivery of the document to sign and return.
If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me. We wish you the best moving forward.

 

Sincerely, 

Maureen

 

Maureen Calabrese
Chief People Officer
Sprout Social
773-304-4185
@mcalabrese312
www.sproutsocial.com
Pronouns: she, her, hers

 

Best,

Maureen

Sprout Social

Re: Update on Onsite Scheduling!
body:
Oh, sweet! Not sure what that is, but sounds fun. This Friday and next Monday are pretty open!

On November 12, 2018 at 2:23:23 PM, Lori Yunk (lori.yunk@endurance.com) wrote:

Hey Matt,

We have Innojam happening this week, and most of our UX team is booked up all day Wednesday and Thursday for that local event!  I'm just finding out now, after getting my feelers out there on availability to greet and spend time with you for an onsite.  Can we perhaps look at other possible days and times?

I thank you for the new set of availability!!

On Fri, Sep 7, 2018 at 1:53 PM Maureen Calabrese <maureen@sproutsocial.com> wrote:

Hi Matt - 

 As a follow-up to our slack, here is some additional information for you as you wrap things up.  I'll be sending your severance agreement at the beginning of next week.  As always, if you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me.

 

1. Pay & Benefits

You will receive pay through 9/7/18. Your paycheck on 9/15/18 will cover the period of 8/24/18 through 9/7/18.
Your benefits are active through 9/30/18.
As part of your severance package and in exchange for a signed release Sprout will pay for COBRA for October and November. In order to receive this benefit, you will need to actively enroll in COBRA. Within 15 days of  the end of your date of coverage on 9/30/18, you will receive enrollment materials from a company called TASC. You can enroll anytime within 60 days from your effective date and the coverage will be retroactive back to 10/1/18.
 

2. Stock Options

The ability to exercise your options expires 30 days from your departure date. 
You can choose to purchase none, some, or all of the options that you are vested in as of your departure date.'
 Please reach out to Tiffany Doyle (cc’ed) with questions or to move forward with the exercising process
 

3. Accounts

We will put all of your accounts on hold for 30 days, followed by deletion and archiving.
If you need anything (computer files, email, etc), please let me know during that time.
 

4. Contact Info

Please send any address changes to peopleops@sproutsocial.com at least through the end of this calendar year. This will ensure timely receipt of your W2 and/or other important communications related to your benefits.
 

5. Equipment Return

We will be shipping boxes with return address labels for you to be able to return your equipment.  Please be on the lookout and let us know if you need anything further.
 

6. Separation Agreement 

In exchange for signing a General Release and Separation agreement, you will be eligible to receive a severance payment of $32,728.13.  This includes your $5,000 referral bonus for Mig.
The agreement will be sent to your personal e-mail address via DocuSign.
You have 5 (five) business days from date of delivery of the document to sign and return.
If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me. We wish you the best moving forward.

 

Sincerely, 

Maureen

 

Maureen Calabrese
Chief People Officer
Sprout Social
773-304-4185
@mcalabrese312
www.sproutsocial.com
Pronouns: she, her, hers

 

Best,

Maureen

Maureen Calabrese
Chief People Officer
Sprout Social
773-304-4185
@mcalabrese312
www.sproutsocial.com
Pronouns: she, her, hers

subject: Re: Great News! Let's get you scheduled for an interview
body:
Happy Monday, Lori!

Thank you for rallying folks on my behalf! I have lunch commitments Wednesday and Thursday. Could we do the full 3.5 hours in the morning or afternoon of either of those days?

Looking forward to it!

Matt

On November 12, 2018 at 11:53:37 AM, Lori Yunk (lori.yunk@endurance.com) wrote:

Hi Matt,

Happy Monday to you sir.  We're ready to get you scheduled to come in and have an onsite interview with our team.  I thank you for allowing me to get with everyone last week on instructions so we'd be ready for next steps with you.  This is about a 3.5 hour event, to offer a heads up on the time commitment.  Can you reply back with your days and times you could be available this week for us?  From there, I'll check everyone's calendars and be back in touch with all the details and the plan so we can get you prepped.

Looking forward to your reply!

Lori Yunk
Endurance/Bluehost Recruiting

subject: Relevant work samples
body:
Happy Monday, Omar!

During our call, I promised some mobile work samples and that social post strategy for churches I had riffed on recently.

Here’s a screenshot of the social post strategy:



Makes me curious how relevant you think this is in the context of your world.

A couple weeks ago, I worked on a design exercise for Underbelly, an agency in downtown Salt Lake. Here is the preso including the slides, a video which gives a good idea at how I start projects with research, and a few high-fidelity mobile concepts: http://bit.ly/ubroadtrippin

At Sprout, I led design on our advocacy product for our desktop, mobile web, and native iOS & Android apps. I took this from zero-to-one, helped build out a team of 50+ people including 3 designers who reported to me, and reached $4M+ in revenue. Here’s the App Store page: https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/bambu-by-sprout-social/id1137159530

Let me know if you want me to dig up more source files for that.

I want to get to a point where I am as prolific as this guy only with millions of users like Instasize: https://project365.design

That’s all for now. Let me know when I can swing by your space!

Cheers,
Matt

subject: Bug Report (kinda): NightOwl 0.2.7 on macOS 10.14
body:
System Information (Please don't change):
*OS:10.14.1*App:0.2.7*Time:1541713149.865666*RunBoot:true*Sound:1*DisabledStatistics:0*Sun:1*Timed:0*

Bug Description:
Control + Command is not a good default hot key because ⌃ + ⌘ + [something] is a common hotkey sequence—emoji flyout, force reboot, window resizing utilities, and Adobe products. Easy to turn off and modify, but made me anxious bumping into it and realizing it automatically disabled the Sunrise/Sunset setting.

Had you considered other defaults? Maybe consider adding an o to the end like so: ⌃ + ⌘ + o?

Thank you!

subject: Re: Following up...
body:
Adam, you are so awesome! Thank you for taking the time to write this!

Truly I say to you, these things don’t come as a surprise and I am extremely grateful for this feedback. Especially since it’s coming from people who need to know this at the start.

On the first point, I know I am not the strongest visual or interaction designer and I never intend to be. But like I said to Wade Shearer on the first day of my job hunt, I’d love to prove you wrong and impress you. Give me a day to dig up some past interactive examples. In the meantime, here is something I just whipped up in an hour today for Clayton & JJ over at Bluehost because they said their site still feels like it’s 2004: https://ws4.sinaimg.cn/large/006tNbRwly1fx09haemgpj31kw4261l4.jpg

On the other 2 points, I’ll just say this is something I’ve always struggled with, but I’ve received feedback from everyone I’ve managed and worked with the past year that I am steadily and noticeably improving. My goal is to find someone to help me maintain a podcast because it’s something I haven’t tried yet to see if having a reliable outlet for my theories would make it easier for me to compartmentalize that side of my creativity.

Remember that Originals book I was telling you about? Check out some of these pull quotes:
“On matters of style, swim with the current,” Thomas Jefferson allegedly advised, but “on matters of principle, stand like a rock.” The pressure to achieve leads us to do the opposite.
Having a sense of security in one realm gives us the freedom to be original in another.
“The best entrepreneurs are not risk maximizers. … They take the risk out of risk-taking.”
The biggest barrier to originality is not idea generation; it’s idea selection.
I believe my passionate verbal dissent comes from my background of working with people who don’t understand why validation is important. Based on the first part of your email and my experiences with everyone at Underbelly so far, it seems like I won’t have to worry about this as much. The people who have worked with me most understand I thrive under constraint including deadlines and definition of done which is frankly something the product world really struggles with.

I want to swim with Underbelly’s current. I want to learn from ya’ll. I want to help our clients and our team mitigate risk. I want to practice insane focus and listening.

Stay tuned for more work samples.

Deeply grateful,

Matt

On November 7, 2018 at 4:29:41 PM, Adam Tolman (adam@underbelly.is) wrote:

Hey Matt, 

Thanks again for your patience in hearing back from Underbelly. I’m grateful you’re not in a hurry :) This is going to be a longer email as I wanted to share all feedback as I thought that would be beneficial for you.

TL;DR - The team and I like you, think you’d fit in well, and think your deep product strategy, vision, research, validation, and development expertise would help bolster the teams confidence in those areas – which would be valuable. With that said, there is concern that this higher level product thinking would take priority of simply getting the work done, as some felt like they did not see a level of craft in interaction and visual design that would be ideal for this position.

Going deeper...

After sharing your design exercise with the leadership team (the longer one), and after talking with Autumn, Jeff, and Britney about their validation sessions with you, here are some pieces of positive feedback I wanted to share:

References were great - We liked what we heard from your references. It’s clear that you’ve demonstrated value to the teams you’ve worked with in the past, particularly in your abilities as a “unicorn”. Your depth of skill in web dev, bridging the gap between what's designed and what ships, presents a lot of obvious value, in addition to being a visionary, good communicator, and more.
Focus on research and validation - The whole team thought that you had deep and demonstrable skills in conducting research sessions and validating your work (shown in your design exercise). This is an area where the team at large is less confident and where you could add a lot of value to our work and process.
Leading kickoffs and discovery sessions - Your experience leading sprints, kickoffs, research, and validation sessions is also a huge plus, as that is one of the core responsibilities of this role. You have good soft skills and can "run a room". This is big as we need someone else on the team to do this.
Developing product strategy - It’s clear you care a lot about digging into the “why” of a project, mapping things to a vision and strategy, making sure that there is significant discovery done and that everything maps back to solving a problem. This is critical.
Focus on growth - You clearly care about learning and improving your craft, utilizing the best processes, methods, and tools, this is an example that we’d like to see set for the rest of the team.
Ability to mentor - You have experience in mentorship and like to work well with others. Core for this role.
Culture fit - People thought you were a cool dude and would fit in well… obviously important.

And some potential concerns (or opportunities for growth):

Potential lack of strong craft - Specifically craft in visual design, with some potential concern with interaction design. Part of this is likely due to you not having enough time to put together polished deliverables for the design exercise, but some thought they didn’t see the chops they’d expect at this level in other work you’ve shared.
Follow up: There are a couple ways we could solve this in the short term. First would be for you to share some high fidelity visual and interactive design work that goes into more detail than what’s shared on your site. Things that show focus on composition and typography (in UI specifically). Bonus points for sharing any motion prototypes that you’ve created. Another option here would be to pay you for spending a bit more time on the design exercise, focusing on the UI. Your call.
Focus on theory/interests over work - This is kind of implied in other things I’ve said, but there is concern that you may talk more about the ideal case, best practices, or philosophical theories of design rather than simply getting things done and making a quick impact. Or be too connected to what you feel is best to be objective on best next steps. Frankly, part of this may be the nature of the interview process, but overall our team seeks to prioritize work over theory/ideals, which is why there is some concern here.
Follow up: Some of this would have to come later as we have you work on your own client projects and provide direction on 1-2 others to see how things unfold.
Lack of brevity - Coming from the team and from references, there is concern about brevity in speech – prioritizing talk over action, and generally being "long-winded" when it may not be necessary. I’m not totally concerned about this, as over communication is better than little communication, but it is worth mentioning.
Follow up: This may just be a mindfulness thing, and am less concerned with this as communication is going to be core to the success of the role.

Hopefully these things don’t come as a surprise and you’re grateful to get the feedback. The follow up items I listed above are meant to be some next steps we could take to build more confidence in those areas and ease concerns, specifically the feedback on craft. 

At this point, my gut tells me that you’d be a great fit for the team and I’d like to bring you on. That said, if we can help quell some concerns from the team—at least in the first area—I know that the rest of the team would be 100% on board. 

Let me know what thoughts or questions you have with that. Would be happy to discuss more in person!

Cheers.

-- 
Adam Tolman
Design Director
underbelly.is C 801.599.5709
