On Fri, Sep 7, 2018 at 1:53 PM Maureen Calabrese <maureen@sproutsocial.com> wrote:

Hi Matt - 

 As a follow-up to our slack, here is some additional information for you as you wrap things up.  I'll be sending your severance agreement at the beginning of next week.  As always, if you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me.

 

1. Pay & Benefits

You will receive pay through 9/7/18. Your paycheck on 9/15/18 will cover the period of 8/24/18 through 9/7/18.
Your benefits are active through 9/30/18.
As part of your severance package and in exchange for a signed release Sprout will pay for COBRA for October and November. In order to receive this benefit, you will need to actively enroll in COBRA. Within 15 days of  the end of your date of coverage on 9/30/18, you will receive enrollment materials from a company called TASC. You can enroll anytime within 60 days from your effective date and the coverage will be retroactive back to 10/1/18.
 

2. Stock Options

The ability to exercise your options expires 30 days from your departure date. 
You can choose to purchase none, some, or all of the options that you are vested in as of your departure date.'
 Please reach out to Tiffany Doyle (cc’ed) with questions or to move forward with the exercising process
 

3. Accounts

We will put all of your accounts on hold for 30 days, followed by deletion and archiving.
If you need anything (computer files, email, etc), please let me know during that time.
 

4. Contact Info

Please send any address changes to peopleops@sproutsocial.com at least through the end of this calendar year. This will ensure timely receipt of your W2 and/or other important communications related to your benefits.
 

5. Equipment Return

We will be shipping boxes with return address labels for you to be able to return your equipment.  Please be on the lookout and let us know if you need anything further.
 

6. Separation Agreement 

In exchange for signing a General Release and Separation agreement, you will be eligible to receive a severance payment of $32,728.13.  This includes your $5,000 referral bonus for Mig.
The agreement will be sent to your personal e-mail address via DocuSign.
You have 5 (five) business days from date of delivery of the document to sign and return.
If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me. We wish you the best moving forward.

 

Sincerely, 

Maureen

 

Maureen Calabrese
Chief People Officer
Sprout Social
773-304-4185
@mcalabrese312
www.sproutsocial.com
Pronouns: she, her, hers

 

Best,

Maureen

Maureen Calabrese
Chief People Officer
Sprout Social
773-304-4185
@mcalabrese312
www.sproutsocial.com
Pronouns: she, her, hers

subject: Re: Instructure
body:
Jesh,

Thank you for your candor and detailed articulation in all your responses! This gives me a very good idea about what to expect.

Not going to bother you with more questions for now, but I am definitely looking forward to another in-person conversation with you. Thank you for being so generous with your time!

Matt

On November 1, 2018 at 2:20:10 PM, Jesh Barlow (jbarlow@instructure.com) wrote:

Ok, I think I follow. So, I would divide up my day (which will be different from others on the team) like so:

20% Product Meetings (hashing out patterns, reviewing/critiquing work, communicating progress, structured collaboration, etc)
10% Social breaks (big part of building trust)
20% Organic collaboration with functional team (PMs, Engineers)
30% Progress on deliverables
15% Learning (research, skill/career development, hacking workflows, etc.)
5% Miscellaneous

Don’t read too much into the percentages, it’s just a guess. But the amount of time I work on anything not related to the product, customers, or user experience is pretty minimal, peppered throughout these percentages. I guess I consider things like interpersonal issues, team building, and process tweaks “internal", but you could argue the results of that work is for the customer, so it depends on where you draw the line on diminishing returns.

👍🏻 Happy to answer anything else!

On Oct 31, 2018, at 11:21 PM, Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:

This is great, thanks so much! For the first one, I meant customer and user problems instead of internal ones. At Sprout it ebbed and flowed, but there were times when I was spending 80%+ of my time on internal problems which I didn’t really enjoy.

On Wed, Oct 31, 2018 at 10:46 PM Jesh Barlow <jbarlow@instructure.com> wrote:
Hey Matt, sorry for the delay. These are tough questions! haha

1. How much of your time is spent solving external problems?

Depends on what you mean by external. Problems that show up that aren’t a part of what I would consider “my job" are super rare, if that’s what you mean, but you may not and what we each consider external probably differs. There’s still gobs of organizational, process, and interpersonal problems to solve, tho. Will you provide an example or clarify a bit?

2. Can you think of a time when a peer was rewarded for dissent over conformity?

Yeah, for sure! (if you mean dissent in a positive way, such as reasonable objections and trailblazing, rather than obtuse resistance without constructive purpose) This is an actual measurement of success at Instructure. We value individual thinking, folks who push the envelope, and regular innovation. I push the norms every day. I disagree with clear reasoning in just about every structured and organic meeting I’m a part of. There are places where conformity matters, such as consistency in the product experience and within familiar conventions, but the culture here is to make stuff better in every way throughout every day, and you can’t do that if you acquiesce. A good example is recently we gave a PM some room to spread his wings with research in a way that was pretty out of the ordinary, and the reaction has been really strong. My PM and I did similar radical research and it ended by making a Career product instead of the Succession Planning product we were charged with at the time, and I feel like it’s worked out really well for us. We create safe environments for this culture to exist. Take a close look at our Bridge product and you’ll see innovations everywhere (happy to walk you through some of it). There isn’t just one smart person calling all the shots here. We only hire super talented, intelligent, and passionate people. Lots of strong opinions that are well-stated but loosely held and eventual consensus make better products. :)

3. Can you describe a team leader besides Devin who rewards process over luck?

Do you mean similarly to a teacher rewarding students for solving math equations when showing work rather than guessing the answer? As in a designer being rewarded for lots of research, exploration, synthesis, ideation, and confidence before delivery? Or an product manager being rewarded for understanding the tough problems really well through lots of communication and empathy, rather than guessing? Too bad this isn’t as straightforward as math, haha. There’s always an important luck factor in everything we do (that or providence, depending on what you believe). I think we’re all guessing to varying degrees. It’s also difficult to track what comes from process and what comes from luck. We as humans have so many innate biases that even the most aware researchers conclude imperfections in synthesis and conclusions. That said, employees who go all out to solve problems are usually the most valued. But if you mean the kind of process that PgMs use to keep everyone on track, I think we use just enough, and only PgMs are rewarded for that kind of process. There’s definitely folks, including myself, that kick against arbitrary deadlines and padded estimates, but regular checkins and realistic roadmaps are critical to delivery. On the flip-side, I can’t think of a single person or team that’s been rewarded for being lucky. Hope this answers your question. Didn’t want to punt like I did on your first question, haha

Thanks Matt! Get back to me on the first one and as always, happy to answer any other questions you have.
- Jesh


On Oct 29, 2018, at 1:41 PM, Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:

Jesh, thank you for an equally thoughtful answer!

This is so positive and it speaks volumes how you champion Instructure’s culture. That said, I don’t want to work where there aren’t massive problems to solve. 😉 Three more questions if you have the time:

1. How much of your time is spent solving external problems?
2. Can you think of a time when a peer was rewarded for dissent over conformity?
3. Can you describe a team leader besides Devin who rewards process over luck?

Thanks again for letting me grill you!

Matt
🙌 trust is foundational to influence

On October 29, 2018 at 10:20:12 AM, Jesh Barlow (jbarlow@instructure.com) wrote:

You bet!

This is a super thoughtful question. Thanks for asking. In general, I’ve found that personal relationships that start with respect and end with empathy and vulnerability sow seeds that grow into trust, and trust is foundational to influence. So I work a lot on this. For designers specifically, succinct and thoughtful decision-, fact-, and opinion-articulation and collaboration with graceful concession is critical. For engineers, intimately understanding the medium (as you mentioned) and respecting limitations, laced with humor works well. For non-product folks, simply listening for concerns and sharing ownership in the problems they face does wonders.

I have this trust-based relationship with my manager, Devin. He’s really good at listening to and considering the changes I suggest. Usually, he’s taken those suggestions and multiplied them in new ways that end up better than I imagined. But honestly, we each have enough autonomy that managing up is rarely needed. I’ve never had a VP+ stop me from solving problems. It’s one of the special things about Instructure. My hunch is that if you were to work here, you’d feel very fulfilled with the potential for impact.

We’ve recently had some changes at the product VP level, so it’ll be interesting to see how to work with them specifically, but in the past, what I mentioned above has worked well. I’ve had plenty of face-time with the CEO and VPs working on this new Career project and everyone is accessible by culture, but like anywhere, there’s a good measure of the executive-presence skill needed for sure.

Hope that answers your question. I’m happy to answer more!

Thanks,
- Jesh

On Oct 26, 2018, at 5:28 PM, Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:

You too, Jesh! Had a blast meeting ya’ll. I really appreciate this follow up.

I’m curious about your personal experience exercising influence at all levels—your fellow designers, engineers, and non-product folks, laterally to more senior folks in those disciplines, and “managing up” to your manager or other VP+ folks. What has worked well for you so far and where have you met the most resistance?

Thank you!

Matt

On October 26, 2018 at 12:22:41 PM, Jesh Barlow (jbarlow@instructure.com) wrote:

Hey Matt, 

Thanks so much for coming in today and taking the time. Was great to meet you.  

Just wanted to reach out and answer any questions you may have about Instructure from a perspective biased differently from others. 

Thanks again! 
- Jesh

subject: Some of the things we talked about
body:
Blake,

Thanks again for your time this morning! I really enjoyed connecting with
you again.

Here are some of the things we talked about:

My new *mentorship curriculum* (WIP) I am starting with a new student next
week:
https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Javascript-Mentorship-Curriculum-AQe0Bj2nl9Tekn1VS8zG8UYFAg-UYJPLOu5wASv7iR7bHDPR

*Burn parties:* after a deeper look, it turns out it originated at Heroku,
and they actually physically burned things. My team at Sprout didn’t take
it that far. It’s a little past halfway through this article:
https://brandur.org/minimalism

What next? Let’s work on something together to help people level up.

*Ethnograph:* The Shortcut to Meaningful Work
Just made that title up, but you never know what your magnum opus will be.
🙂

The *church* I helped start: http://ridgelineslc.com
Our first Sunday video:
https://www.facebook.com/Ryanhuguley/videos/10156650931470967/

Until next time…

Matt

subject: Re: Instructure
body:
Jesh, thank you for an equally thoughtful answer!

This is so positive and it speaks volumes how you champion Instructure’s culture. That said, I don’t want to work where there aren’t massive problems to solve. 😉 Three more questions if you have the time:

1. How much of your time is spent solving external problems?
2. Can you think of a time when a peer was rewarded for dissent over conformity?
3. Can you describe a team leader besides Devin who rewards process over luck?

Thanks again for letting me grill you!

Matt
🙌 trust is foundational to influence

On October 29, 2018 at 10:20:12 AM, Jesh Barlow (jbarlow@instructure.com) wrote:

You bet!

This is a super thoughtful question. Thanks for asking. In general, I’ve found that personal relationships that start with respect and end with empathy and vulnerability sow seeds that grow into trust, and trust is foundational to influence. So I work a lot on this. For designers specifically, succinct and thoughtful decision-, fact-, and opinion-articulation and collaboration with graceful concession is critical. For engineers, intimately understanding the medium (as you mentioned) and respecting limitations, laced with humor works well. For non-product folks, simply listening for concerns and sharing ownership in the problems they face does wonders.

I have this trust-based relationship with my manager, Devin. He’s really good at listening to and considering the changes I suggest. Usually, he’s taken those suggestions and multiplied them in new ways that end up better than I imagined. But honestly, we each have enough autonomy that managing up is rarely needed. I’ve never had a VP+ stop me from solving problems. It’s one of the special things about Instructure. My hunch is that if you were to work here, you’d feel very fulfilled with the potential for impact.

We’ve recently had some changes at the product VP level, so it’ll be interesting to see how to work with them specifically, but in the past, what I mentioned above has worked well. I’ve had plenty of face-time with the CEO and VPs working on this new Career project and everyone is accessible by culture, but like anywhere, there’s a good measure of the executive-presence skill needed for sure.

Hope that answers your question. I’m happy to answer more!

Thanks,
- Jesh

On Oct 26, 2018, at 5:28 PM, Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:

You too, Jesh! Had a blast meeting ya’ll. I really appreciate this follow up.

I’m curious about your personal experience exercising influence at all levels—your fellow designers, engineers, and non-product folks, laterally to more senior folks in those disciplines, and “managing up” to your manager or other VP+ folks. What has worked well for you so far and where have you met the most resistance?

Thank you!

Matt

On October 26, 2018 at 12:22:41 PM, Jesh Barlow (jbarlow@instructure.com) wrote:

Hey Matt, 

Thanks so much for coming in today and taking the time. Was great to meet you.  

Just wanted to reach out and answer any questions you may have about Instructure from a perspective biased differently from others. 

Thanks again! 
- Jesh

On Mon, Oct 22, 2018 at 6:09 AM Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:
This is great, thank you! My goal is to spend a good chunk of time on this today and tomorrow and deliver my progress by Wednesday.

On Sun, Oct 21, 2018 at 11:25 PM Adam Tolman <adam@underbelly.is> wrote:
Hey Matt, hope you had a good weekend.

Really sorry for not replying sooner here, just catching up. Really stoked on your thinking already, and would generally say you're going down the right track. Really into the product thinking you’re applying here, especially from a brain dump.

And stoked to see you asking logical questions, this is a good sign :) Here are some brief answers, but happy to discuss further if you’d like…

Dealing with constraints are part of the real world, especially at an agency (obviously), but part of this exercise is purposely seeing what you choose to focus in when there is no clear cut direction. If you want to put in place some logical constraints as a way of moving the design forward, feel free.
Get crazy, involve whoever you want here. Can be public, I don’t really have a problem with that.
I love the idea of you doing validation tests with folks at Underbelly. That’s a great idea. Let’s make this happen sometime this week, just text me and we can coordinate details.
You’re totally on the right track. The way you’re breaking this down demonstrates a great deal of your process and thinking already, and that’s totally the point.

Also, I saw that you may elect to use UX Power Tools for the UI/visual design, which makes a ton of sense for moving more quickly to validate the product (again, thinking of the real world). With that said, I would encourage you to put some more time into the UI/visual design, potentially using that as a means of solving the problem in a way that may differentiate the product. Unique, polished visual design goes along way here, especially once we’ve seen deep product/design thinking.

Anyway, hopefully that helps, but I’m more than happy to answer any other questions.

Thanks for taking the time, man!

-- 
Adam Tolman
Design Director
underbelly.is C 801.599.5709

On Oct 19, 2018, at 1:48 PM, Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:

Adam,

My goal today is to craft a schedule to work on this next week starting Monday, but I read through the PDF and spent an hour capturing my initial brain dump: 

<roadtrip-initial-thoughts.png>

Some questions:

* Should I treat this exercise as a hypothetical of someone with deep pockets funding a hunch-based moonshot and ignore real world business constraints related to budget, resources, timeline, orchestration, etc.?
* Are there any restrictions on making my work public or involving others—including strangers?
* If I set up 2 non-negotiable validation tests or mock client/stakeholder reviews next week, would that be something I could get a couple Underbelly folks to spare 45 mins of their time or should I do something like that with my own people?
* Friend zone moment: Am I on the right track or do you have any tips to help me shrink the universe?

Thanks for your help in advance!

Matt

subject: Re: Instructure
body:
You too, Jesh! Had a blast meeting ya’ll. I really appreciate this follow up.

I’m curious about your personal experience exercising influence at all levels—your fellow designers, engineers, and non-product folks, laterally to more senior folks in those disciplines, and “managing up” to your manager or other VP+ folks. What has worked well for you so far and where have you met the most resistance?

Thank you!

Matt

On October 26, 2018 at 12:22:41 PM, Jesh Barlow (jbarlow@instructure.com) wrote:

Hey Matt,  

Thanks so much for coming in today and taking the time. Was great to meet you.  

Just wanted to reach out and answer any questions you may have about Instructure from a perspective biased differently from others.  

Thanks again!  
- Jesh

subject: Re: Design Proficiency Exercise
body:
Morning, Adam!

Here’s the video I promised!  https://youtu.be/wp0It34ISEQ

It’s a big long (22+ min), but it covers my process, design work, and time
with Underbelly folks Wednesday afternoon.

Let me know what you think!

Matt

On Mon, Oct 22, 2018 at 6:09 AM Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:

> This is great, thank you! My goal is to spend a good chunk of time on this
> today and tomorrow and deliver my progress by Wednesday.
>
> On Sun, Oct 21, 2018 at 11:25 PM Adam Tolman <adam@underbelly.is> wrote:
>
>> Hey Matt, hope you had a good weekend.
>>
>> Really sorry for not replying sooner here, just catching up. Really
>> stoked on your thinking already, and would generally say you're going down
>> the right track. Really into the product thinking you’re applying here,
>> especially from a brain dump.
>>
>> And stoked to see you asking logical questions, this is a good sign :)
>> Here are some brief answers, but happy to discuss further if you’d like…
>>
>>
>>    - Dealing with constraints are part of the real world, especially at
>>    an agency (obviously), but part of this exercise is *purposely*
>>    seeing what you choose to focus in when there is no clear cut direction. If
>>    you want to put in place some logical constraints as a way of moving the
>>    design forward, feel free.
>>    - Get crazy, involve whoever you want here. Can be public, I don’t
>>    really have a problem with that.
>>    - I love the idea of you doing validation tests with folks at
>>    Underbelly. That’s a great idea. Let’s make this happen sometime this week,
>>    just text me and we can coordinate details.
>>    - You’re totally on the right track. The way you’re breaking this
>>    down demonstrates a great deal of your process and thinking already, and
>>    that’s totally the point.
>>
>>
>> Also, I saw that you may elect to use UX Power Tools for the UI/visual
>> design, which makes a ton of sense for moving more quickly to validate the
>> product (again, thinking of the real world). With that said, I would
>> encourage you to put some more time into the UI/visual design, potentially
>> using that as a means of solving the problem in a way that may
>> differentiate the product. Unique, polished visual design goes along way
>> here, especially once we’ve seen deep product/design thinking.
>>
>> Anyway, hopefully that helps, but I’m more than happy to answer any other
>> questions.
>>
>> Thanks for taking the time, man!
>>
>> --
>> *Adam Tolman*
>> Design Director <http://www.underbelly.co/>
>> *underbelly.is <http://www.underbelly.is/>*
>> C 801.599.5709
>>
>> On Oct 19, 2018, at 1:48 PM, Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:
>>
>> Adam,
>>
>> My goal today is to craft a schedule to work on this next week starting
>> Monday, but I read through the PDF and spent an hour capturing my initial
>> brain dump:
>>
>> <roadtrip-initial-thoughts.png>
>>
>> Some questions:
>>
>> * Should I treat this exercise as a hypothetical of someone with deep
>> pockets funding a hunch-based moonshot and ignore real world business
>> constraints related to budget, resources, timeline, orchestration, etc.?
>> * Are there any restrictions on making my work public or involving
>> others—including strangers?
>> * If I set up 2 non-negotiable validation tests or mock
>> client/stakeholder reviews next week, would that be something I could get a
>> couple Underbelly folks to spare 45 mins of their time or should I do
>> something like that with my own people?
>> * Friend zone moment: Am I on the right track or do you have any tips to
>> help me shrink the universe?
>>
>> Thanks for your help in advance!
>>
>> Matt
>>
>>
>>

body:

today and tomorrow and deliver my progress by Wednesday.

On Sun, Oct 21, 2018 at 11:25 PM Adam Tolman <adam@underbelly.is> wrote:

> Hey Matt, hope you had a good weekend.
>
> Really sorry for not replying sooner here, just catching up. Really stoked
> on your thinking already, and would generally say you're going down the
> right track. Really into the product thinking you’re applying here,
> especially from a brain dump.
>
> And stoked to see you asking logical questions, this is a good sign :)
> Here are some brief answers, but happy to discuss further if you’d like…
>
>
>    - Dealing with constraints are part of the real world, especially at
>    an agency (obviously), but part of this exercise is *purposely* seeing
>    what you choose to focus in when there is no clear cut direction. If you
>    want to put in place some logical constraints as a way of moving the design
>    forward, feel free.
>    - Get crazy, involve whoever you want here. Can be public, I don’t
>    really have a problem with that.
>    - I love the idea of you doing validation tests with folks at
>    Underbelly. That’s a great idea. Let’s make this happen sometime this week,
>    just text me and we can coordinate details.
>    - You’re totally on the right track. The way you’re breaking this down
>    demonstrates a great deal of your process and thinking already, and that’s
>    totally the point.
>
>
> Also, I saw that you may elect to use UX Power Tools for the UI/visual
> design, which makes a ton of sense for moving more quickly to validate the
> product (again, thinking of the real world). With that said, I would
> encourage you to put some more time into the UI/visual design, potentially
> using that as a means of solving the problem in a way that may
> differentiate the product. Unique, polished visual design goes along way
> here, especially once we’ve seen deep product/design thinking.
>
> Anyway, hopefully that helps, but I’m more than happy to answer any other
> questions.
>
> Thanks for taking the time, man!
>
> --
> *Adam Tolman*
> Design Director <http://www.underbelly.co/>
> *underbelly.is <http://www.underbelly.is/>*
> C 801.599.5709
>

On Thu, Oct 18, 2018 at 10:41 PM Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:

> Sure, I'd be happy to! Underbelly is my front runner, too. 😉
>
> Thanks for staying up late for this, Adam! Will send those references soon.
>
> On Thu, Oct 18, 2018 at 10:38 PM Adam Tolman <adam@underbelly.is> wrote:
>
>> Hey Matt,
>>
>> Thanks for your time over the last couple weeks, meeting the team,
>> chatting more about the role, and spending time getting to know the agency
>> and the people that make it what it is. Hopefully it’s been a useful way
>> for you to evaluate the team/gig to see if it’s a good fit. It was good for
>> us to understand your background, skills, and experience, and it was a
>> pleasure to get to know you better.
>>
>> So... I wanted to follow up on some things we wanted to do next after
>> talking to Anthony and the crew, and wanted to get your thoughts on the
>> following:
>>
>>
>>    - *Sharing references* - We’d like to contact a few folks that you’ve
>>    worked with in the past to get their thoughts on working with you as a
>>    means of getting additional signal on your strengths, weaknesses, etc.
>>    Hopefully you can share a few contacts with us.
>>    - *Design proficiency exercise* - We’d like to pay you to complete a
>>    design exercise for us as a means of evaluating your approach,
>>    conceptualization, and execution on a standalone design project. You can
>>    see the details in the attached doc. Let me know if you’re game.
>>    - *Grab lunch with Riley* - You had wanted to do this anyway, but I
>>    thought it would be cool for you and Riley to get together over lunch and
>>    talk shop. This could give you a better idea on how we can bring design and
>>    dev closer together at Underbelly.
>>
>>
>> Hopefully this doesn’t feel like you're going through a
>> longer-than-necessary process. Ultimately we want to be sure we’re making
>> the right decision (the whole hire slow, fire fast model), and this is the
>> means to do that. Hopefully that resonates with you.
>>
>> Also, for what it’s worth, by most accounts you have been the
>> front-runner as we’ve interviewed several other candidates, so this is more
>> of a due diligence / gut check thing than anything else.
>>
>> Anyway, definitely hit me up and let me know what questions/concerns you
>> have.
>>
>> Thanks, man! Talk soon!
>>
>> --
>> *Adam Tolman*
>> Design Director <http://www.underbelly.co/>
>> *underbelly.is <http://www.underbelly.is/>*
>> C 801.599.5709
>>
>>

subject: Re: Following Up on Next Steps...
body:
Sure, I'd be happy to! Underbelly is my front runner, too. 😉

Thanks for staying up late for this, Adam! Will send those references soon.

On Thu, Oct 18, 2018 at 10:38 PM Adam Tolman <adam@underbelly.is> wrote:

> Hey Matt,
>
> Thanks for your time over the last couple weeks, meeting the team,
> chatting more about the role, and spending time getting to know the agency
> and the people that make it what it is. Hopefully it’s been a useful way
> for you to evaluate the team/gig to see if it’s a good fit. It was good for
> us to understand your background, skills, and experience, and it was a
> pleasure to get to know you better.
>
> So... I wanted to follow up on some things we wanted to do next after
> talking to Anthony and the crew, and wanted to get your thoughts on the
> following:
>
>
>    - *Sharing references* - We’d like to contact a few folks that you’ve
>    worked with in the past to get their thoughts on working with you as a
>    means of getting additional signal on your strengths, weaknesses, etc.
>    Hopefully you can share a few contacts with us.
>    - *Design proficiency exercise* - We’d like to pay you to complete a
>    design exercise for us as a means of evaluating your approach,
>    conceptualization, and execution on a standalone design project. You can
>    see the details in the attached doc. Let me know if you’re game.
>    - *Grab lunch with Riley* - You had wanted to do this anyway, but I
>    thought it would be cool for you and Riley to get together over lunch and
>    talk shop. This could give you a better idea on how we can bring design and
>    dev closer together at Underbelly.
>
>
> Hopefully this doesn’t feel like you're going through a
> longer-than-necessary process. Ultimately we want to be sure we’re making
> the right decision (the whole hire slow, fire fast model), and this is the
> means to do that. Hopefully that resonates with you.
>
> Also, for what it’s worth, by most accounts you have been the front-runner
> as we’ve interviewed several other candidates, so this is more of a due
> diligence / gut check thing than anything else.
>
> Anyway, definitely hit me up and let me know what questions/concerns you
> have.
>
> Thanks, man! Talk soon!
>
> --
> *Adam Tolman*
> Design Director <http://www.underbelly.co/>
> *underbelly.is <http://www.underbelly.is/>*
> C 801.599.5709
>
>

subject: Re: Belong Lives On
body:
Celeste!

Sorry it took me 6 weeks to respond! You have my support! I am currently still unemployed if you need anything right now. :)

How are things going since you sent this email?

Matt

On Wed, Aug 29, 2018 at 12:46 PM Celeste Cecchi <celeste.n.cecchi@gmail.com> wrote:
OH! And I should probably give you a brief synopsis of the project. I'll copy and paste the initial *informal* proposal I wrote for my academic advisor below (it's easier that way since it was formatted for my school site). 

Matt, I'm not sure how much Eric has shared about my program, but I've been studying social justice with an emphasis in biblical advocacy. (Just though knowing that might help explain the wording/direction I took my proposal.)

.....

  
In his book Pursuing Justice, Ken Wytsma describes how sin and
injustice have torn the fabric of shalom—or the intended wholeness
and flourishing of God’s creation. Wytsma quotes Cornelius
Plantinga, saying, “To be a responsible [Christian] is to find
one’s role in the building of shalom, the re-webbing of God,
humanity, and all creation in justice, harmony, fulfillment, and
delight.”(16)



Desiring to be a responsible [Christian] and therefore find my role
in the rebuilding of shalom, and believing that sin has indeed
broken said shalom, I am proposing the undertaking of The Belong
Marketplace as my thesis.


The Belong Marketplace will be a tool (specifically an
application) for individuals who desire to actively pursue the
rebuilding of shalom through social justice. This app will connect
its users with resources, churches, and organizations currently
fighting to restore brokenness in their communities. The
organizations will also benefit from the app, being connected with
potential volunteers, supporters, and visibility within their
communities.


The goals of my thesis are:


To develop a user-friendly app which compels its users to engage in
social justice by connecting them with local
organizations



To move its users from awareness to action to advocacy by using the
framework of Abraham Maslow’s hierarchy of human needs (which
culminates in human flourishing)



Ultimately though, the goal of my thesis is to restore shalom. As
Wytsma points out, “Without justice there can be no shalom. Shalom
flourishes in the presence of justice. Biblical shalom requires the
active pursuit of what ought to be... [God] wants to undo
the effects of sin and bring about shalom—isn’t that why He sent
Jesus?”(27)  
If God’s ultimate goal in sending Jesus was to restore shalom,
shouldn’t our goal be to join Him in this work?

On Wed, Aug 29, 2018 at 1:28 PM Celeste Cecchi <celeste.n.cecchi@gmail.com> wrote:
Hello lover, sister, and friend! 
(I'll let each of you figure out which of those belongs to you.😉)

Though I suppose this update is primarily for the sake of Matt since I talk to the other two regularly, I thought I'd gather the original Belong sprint team together in this long-overdue update. Obviously you all have stake in this project, having invested time, energy and more, so I thought it was only fair I share a few things with you.

As you know, Belong has been on a sabbatical of sorts for the past couple years. After the second sprint somewhat derailed the vision, I wound up frustrated and in grad school (not a bad alternative). I'm nearing the end of my program now—like, I'm graduating in a few weeks! However, I still have to complete and defend my thesis before I'll officially be given that *most-expensive-piece-of-paper-we-all-have-stuffed-in-a-drawer-somewhere*. And said thesis is the purpose of this email.

So Belong and I may have been on a break for a while, but I couldn't shake it from my heart. There was still something there I felt God wasn't finished with yet. Because of this, I decided to mention it to my academic advisor (half joking) as a potential thesis. I was less than confident that this anything-but-conventional thesis would be approved by her, let alone by the board—and then it was. It was more than approved. It was supported, passed along to higher ups, and then backed in ways I couldn't have imagined it would be. (Read: potential financial backing?!) 

Anyway, long short of it is that Belong is being resuscitated. And that (perhaps combined with nostalgia) compelled me to reach out. 

Firstly, I wanted to thank you ALL for believing in Belong enough to get on board and make a personal investment in it years ago. Honestly, that first sprint is the thing I go back to for vitality on a regular basis. Secondly, I wanted to ask if you're all comfortable with me moving forward with this as my thesis project, knowing it will likely change the dynamics and/or direction we were headed in together at one time. (Again, you are all stakeholders of sorts, so I don't want to claim this as "mine".) Lastly, I am wondering whether or not you would be interested in being an advisor/consultant for the project. I know you're all in different seasons of life and are crazy busy now. The time commitment could be whatever you choose for it to be. Agreeing to being an advisor would basically just mean I list you in my thesis portfolio as a part of my advisory board (this process all sounds so official and grown up hahah!). Beyond that, though, it's up to you how much or how little you want to be involved. For example, I could just bounce ideas off you once in a while, or you could all quit your jobs, move to Chicago, and commit to working on my thesis with me full time from now until December when I have to defend it before the school board.😉

Again, I appreciate the investment you've already made in Belong—you brought it to life! Can’t wait to fill you in about where God takes it from here!😊 

C

subject: Fwd: Details for Spoke Private Pilot
body:
Ya’ll interested in piloting this with me starting next Monday? It’s a platform for improving the way people collaborate remotely.

On October 16, 2018 at 9:56:27 AM, Spoke Beta (spoke.beta@gmail.com) wrote:

Hi Matt,

It was great talking to you and thank you so much for your interest in participating in the Spoke private pilot!

The goal of this pilot is to get feedback about what you do and don't like about Spoke and to learn about how you use it. We're also so excited to offer you early access to a new product designed for remote/distributed teams.

Here's a quick rundown of what to expect:
Pilot testing begins on October 22nd and will last 2 weeks (with the option to extend)
On October 22nd, I'll send you a download link to the Spoke app along with sign up instructions. The app works on iOS only.
Part of the sign up process will include creating a Team Code. After you've created a Team Code, you'll send it to your teammates so that they can join Spoke with you. Make sure that they don't create their own code, otherwise they'll be on a different team!
Please give your teammates a heads up about the pilot this week so they're ready to go when it begins!

FAQ's

Who on my team should I invite to join me?
Spoke works well with people who you need catch up with during the day. These are usually people on your immediate team or who you often work on projects with. Feel free to send out your team code to as many people as you'd like.

When should I use Spoke?
Hop onto Spoke to indicate you're free to talk. Others on your team will get a notification that you've entered the app. If someone on your team needs to run something by you, wants to talk through some ideas or just say hello, they'll hop on too. The same works for your teammates too.

Are my conversations private?
Yes, completely. Your conversations can only be heard by individuals in the app with you. We will collect some general metrics on usage (like hours on the platform). What you say is completely private.

Is there anything I am obligated to do as a tester?
Send us feedback as often as possible! You and your teammates can email spoke.beta@gmail.com or text me at 925.768.4307 whenever anything comes to mind. The more feedback, the better. I'll be checking in occasionally to see how things are going, as well.

///

Please let me know if you have any questions. Can't wait to get started!
Adena

Matt

morning?

Matt

Matt

subject: Work samples
body:
Hey, Patrick!

Bummed we missed our goal to do a code review with Luke on Thursday and
that it has taken me this long to follow up with you. Here are the video
links I tried to share last week:

https://drive.google.com/file/d/170x0EP50mNKNd37e4zyZ-u0BByMaxJCX/view
https://drive.google.com/file/d/171Lh6-B85dIO2i0eLXlXsnVHFhcA6z5G/view

I still need to prepare something for you that shows my depth on
interactive dashboards and data vis. It’s also worth mentioning the product
I designed and coded from scratch is the highest rated in the advocacy
vertical on g2crowd:
https://www.g2crowd.com/products/bambu-by-sprout-social/reviews

Most of this is silly, but here are some of the coded prototypes I made
early on at Sprout (4–6 years old): http://bit.ly/brotado

Last week I prioritized having conversations with several different
companies. That went well, but everyone has asked me to show more of my
work and process so that is my focus right now. I am still really inspired
by our conversation and I don’t want your team to grow suspect so let me
know what I can do to impress them.

Does it make sense for me to connect with Luke so we can jump in the code?

Thank you!

Matt

> the attached exercise form, along with a check (made payable to Sprout
> Social, Inc.) for your total investment cost.  If time is a concern, I can
> send you our bank information so that you can wire your payment to us. You
> you know, you have *30 days* from your last day with Sprout to exercise
> these vested options if you choose to do so.  Once we have your form and
> payment, Sprout will countersign the form and send back to you.  We would
> also request a stock certificate for your exercised shares and send a copy
> of that to you as soon as it becomes available.
>
> Regarding your question around taxes, it is important to note that these
> are ISO’s (incentive stock options), and thus need to be considered during
> your tax filings when evaluating alternative minimum tax (AMT), if
> applicable.  Based on a quick google search, I found this article to be

subject: 3 Ways to Level Up Your Product Org, The Last One Will SCARE You!
body:
(A little birdie told me you liked clickbait copy. 😂)

Seriously, thank you for our time together yesterday. I found it very
encouraging to learn there are leaders like you who champion the
disciplines I’ve fought for in the past. Ended up chatting with Blake for
an hour in the lobby and was really inspired by his story and vision as
well. Here are 3 things that stood out to me (or my interpretation anyway):

1. As design leaders, we replicate user research into every customer-facing
peer. e.g. Understanding your customer’s problem—not their request—makes
you a better salesperson.
2. Nearly all of our customers said they would buy another product from us,
so we are launching several new products the next couple quarters. It *is*
crazy.
3. 👻 We’re excited about design systems, scaling research, and doubling
down on deep prototypes to drive new products—both externally and
internally.

Right now, I want to be hands-on because I haven’t had enough success
bringing novel ideas to market. I also want to find a team who appreciates
a very technical approach to design à la Airbnb. My goal is to work my way
to staff in 1–2 years, principal in 3–4 years, and mentor a dozen more
designers. In 5 years, I want to be qualified for this role (
https://stripe.com/jobs/positions/head-of-product-design) and I know folks
like you and Blake would help me get there.

Some inspiration I mentioned during our conversation:
* Kevin Hale’s talk about every person talking to customers 2 hours per
week including engineers AKA Support Driven Development:
https://youtu.be/sz_LgBAGYyo?t=15m20s
* Tom Chi (dunno why I called him Mike) on Staying in the Medium:
https://www.mindtheproduct.com/2015/07/video-tom-chi-on-rapid-prototyping-product-management/
* Design leadership + management links I maintain with Mig Reyes (didn’t
mention this, but thought I’d share anyways): http://mgmt.design

Thanks again for your time and encouragement! Looking forward to following
up with Blake again soon.

With massive gratitude,
Matt

subject: Re: Lead Motion Designer / Senior Animator
body:
Hey, ya’ll!

I’m not sure I’m qualified for this role, but I’d love an opportunity to impress you. I’m currently looking for a role in product, but mograph has always been something I’ve enjoyed doing on the side.

Here are some past projects:

Ridgeline Logomark, 2018 → https://www.instagram.com/p/BgTpu-GF2ua/ <https://www.instagram.com/p/BgTpu-GF2ua/>

Lion’s Roar, 2006 (collaboration) → https://vimeo.com/344617 <https://vimeo.com/344617>

Christian Freedom International, 2012 → https://vimeo.com/40372438 <https://vimeo.com/40372438>

God is Greater, 2012? → https://drive.google.com/file/d/11tgyRhmkecXp20MZJ2AmyJzLachLSgs_/view <https://drive.google.com/file/d/11tgyRhmkecXp20MZJ2AmyJzLachLSgs_/view>

Restoring Gospel / Community / Mission Series, 2012 → https://www.facebook.com/pg/RedemptionBC/videos/ <https://www.facebook.com/pg/RedemptionBC/videos/>

Good As Gold (no animation, only storytelling), 2017 → https://youtu.be/nrx0O56IwNs <https://youtu.be/nrx0O56IwNs>

Let me know if any of this is what you are looking for. Eager to learn and be challenged. Either way, let’s be friends. :)

Thanks for your time!

Matt

subject: Thanks, Cat!
body:
Cat,

Thank you so much for your time last week! Please excuse all the
long-winded responses. A lot of what you said was inspiring which tends to
make me ramble with new ideas. I’ve preferred small companies so I wasn’t
sure where I landed on a company like Facebook, but you reshaped my
opinion. I wrote this the day after we talked:

> Life is about connecting with people. Facebook is building these
connections. They are probably the best in the world at this. They have the
means to connect almost every living human, and they are investing the
resources to get there. I could be on a team that focuses on this growth
and operates like a small start-up. It’s not primarily about conversion and
revenue; it’s about connection for global equity. Mark is willing to spend
billions to achieve this.

Thank you for your candid responses to my questions! As a reminder, I am
holding you to this statement: *“I’ve never seen anyone put the business
before our users.”* I hope this is true for other companies I am talking to
here in the Salt Lake Valley, and I hope to have the sort of influence that
inspires people to speak as highly as you do about the brand you represent.

A move to Menlo would be tough in this season of life, but we will
entertain this as we plan for our next chapter. You mentioned a call with
someone one the business side. Is that something we could still do now so I
could learn a little more?

Appreciate all your help!

Matt

subject: Re: Form Submission - Contact page form - Looking for more friends in the SLC creative community!
body:
Yes! Thanks for following up, Tony! I usually try to respond right away,
because it’s easy for me to lose track of emails like this.

Utah is wonderful so far. Ridgeline meets in the building that is closer to
the road. I am assuming this is white? The red one is now a club or
something called Commonwealth Room.

Re: creating community with Christian creatives… all sorts of yes. I am
working with dozens of churches all over the country simultaneously via
MyXP.church doing branding, signage, and (hopefully) scalable communication
systems, and I would love to involve other folks to learn and build bridges.

Going to text you now to double-down on my response to you. ;)

subject: Fwd: Issue #1
body:
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Ryan Huguley <ryanhuguley@gmail.com>
Date: Tue, Mar 27, 2018 at 1:22 PM
Subject: Issue #1
To: <me@mattborn.com>


LOOKING BACK:
March 18 was a big day for us. After months of prayer, building
relationship and spreading the word on social media, we had our first
Vision + Worship Night at The Art Factory.

This event started as an experiment. The idea was, rather than simply tell
people about Ridgeline, we wanted to invite them to experience it first
hand.

Our team lead worship and I preached a message from Romans 10:1-15 called
“Losing the Ladder, Receiving the Gift.” We dismantled religion as a means
to climb our way into right relationship with God and instead invited
people to simply receive the gift of grace held out to us by Jesus. We
finished the night off with some text message Q&A, which is always a good
time.

The “experiment” was a success! We had just over 60 adults, a bunch of kids
and a number of people signing up for more information about Ridgeline.

COMING UP:
Sunday marks the kickoff of our Launch Team Worship Services. We’ll have
childcare for infants - kindergarten, acoustic worship, teaching and Q&A.

We’re spending the next five months building up and into our launch team
with a teaching series called “This Is Ridgeline.” We’ll cover some core
doctrinal and practical convictions, as well as doing a deep dive into the
cultural characteristics we want to mark our new church.

Our prayer is to see our team grow to 100 people as we build toward our
public launch in early September.

Help us spread the word! If you’re here in Salt Lake, invite someone to
join you this Sunday at 10a. Call, text, or email a few people, insure them
we’re not psychos and invite them to come check it out, no strings
attached. You can also share our invite video on your Facebook page
https://www.facebook.com/RidgelineSLC/videos/10155534643272896/?notif_id=1522077661456104¬if_t=page_post_reaction
<https://www.facebook.com/RidgelineSLC/videos/10155534643272896/?notif_id=1522077661456104&notif_t=page_post_reaction>.  
We
want the entire Salt Lake Valley to know that Jesus loves them and we do
to.

LAUNCH TEAM SPOTLIGHT:
The newest people courageous enough to move across the country and join our
team are Matt and DeeDee Johnson. I just had the privilege of performing
their wedding last month and as payment they moved to Salt Lake City to
join our church (j/k they were already coming).

Matt is currently working in IT and Deedee is pursuing a job in mental
health social work. Matt serves as one of our worship leaders and Deedee
helps with sound and media. The thing they’re most excited about at
Ridgeline is being a part of building a healthy church culture with great
friends in an area with an immense amount of need.

We’re blessed to have this great couple and excited for how God will use
them.

You can join our team and be a part of all God’s doing in and through
Ridgeline too. Fill out this short form and we’ll get you connected.
https://ridgeline.formstack.com/forms/info_card

SHARING THE LOAD:
Saturday a handful of people on our team all pitched in to do some more
work at The Art Factory. We painted, cleaned and even built some IKEA
furniture without anyone quitting our church (if building IKEA furniture
with a good attitude isn’t a sign of revival, I don’t know what is.
Ridgeline is Jesus’ church and He’s building it through great people like
this.

If you’re interested in sharing the load at Ridgeline in some way, click
here to find the full list of our missional teams to serve on.

LINKS TO STUFF I LOVE:
Read

    - Garden City by John Mark Comer -
     
https://www.amazon.com/Garden-City-Work-Being-Human/dp/0310337348/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1522178145&sr=8-1&keywords=garden+city+john+mark+comer&dpID=317XJ8x6OML&preST=_SY291_BO1
    ,204,203,200_QL40_&dpSrc=srch
    - Kingdom Conspiracy by Scot McKnight -
     
https://www.amazon.com/Kingdom-Conspiracy-Returning-Radical-Mission/dp/0801097851/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1522178187&sr=1-1&keywords=kingdom+conspiracy&dpID=51OOKwGwl2L&preST=_SY291_BO1
    ,204,203,200_QL40_&dpSrc=srch


Listen

    - Whole Heart by Passion -
     
https://open.spotify.com/user/122324635/playlist/2p9plvGxydk9NMPxK1wbAO?si=ttLg805HSE2KVZKtz4H2Xg
    - Good News by Rend Collective -
     
https://open.spotify.com/user/122324635/playlist/4dLR5uFbPa2d86fyizl0kj?si=qk54dMLxSDCKOV_umc3C5g
    - Hallelujah Amen by Vertical Worship -
     
https://open.spotify.com/track/78wyAJJM6TsN428S5ScPg7?si=AVgAfz1ARWSFgCD35kM8wg



*Ryan Huguley*
Twitter <https://twitter.com/ryanhuguley> | Facebook
<https://www.facebook.com/Ryanhuguley> | Instagram
<https://www.instagram.com/ryanhuguley/> | Blog <http://ryanhuguley.com/>

Sent from my iPad

subject: Re: Additional Order
body:
Hey, Mindy!

Thank you for your quick turnaround on these! The dimensions included on
the first set of files were for the artboards and not the artwork itself
which is likely what caused the skewing. In order to get the correct
sizing, I think it would be best if we sent new, combined files with a
common understanding of the final printed size (in inches) including the
margins where they are cut (maybe half inch on all sides). What is the
maximum width and height you are able to print so I know how many separate
files to create?

Thank you for your responsiveness!

subject: Re: Website/Rebrand
body:
Of course! There are many hats in brand and web consulting, so my only
requirement is that we align on which types of decisions you need:

* advising - Why Squarespace?
* researching - identify constraints and inspiration
* configuring - tinkering with Squarespace-specific options
* implementing - producing content or code
* testing - SMART way to prove success (specific, measurable, achievable,
relevant, time-bound)

Our loan was approved, so next is our settlement deadline and closing!

Can you do a call this weekend?

On Mon, Nov 20, 2017 at 12:18 PM Eric Floberg <ericfloberg@gmail.com> wrote:

> Hey dude! I'm looking to redo my website this winter and rebrand. Any
> chance you'd be willing to work with me on it? If so, I'd love to chat on
> the phone or meet up to discuss what you'd charge and what we could do. ;)
> In short, I think I'd like to switch from Wordpress to Squarespace and have
> an artist do a bunch of rebranding for me. Just have to hash out how I want
> to present everything and lay it out. Look forward to talking more soon.
> Hope you guys are doing well!
>
> Also, what's the status on the house??
>
> Best,
> Eric
>
> www.ericfloberg.com
>

subject: Family photos in Elmhurst
body:
Hey, Eric!

Ryan—my partner-in-crime leading the teams on Bambu—saw our Insta’s and
asked for your info. I told him you were my highest recommendation, and if
not you, that you’re well-connected with other talented folks and would
defer to you on another recommendation. Ryan and his wife have 2 little
ones as well.

Consider this a virtual handshake. Feel free to nix me from the thread. :)

Happy Friday!

Matt

subject: Stepping away from Bloc
body:
Hey, Ali!

Hope all is well! I have recently taken on management responsibilities at
Sprout which combined with my growing family is leaving me with very little
time to focus on mentorship. As a result, I am in the process of stepping
away from Bloc.

I just set your account on another 2 week freeze since I figured this would
be a good way to set a buffer for managing expectations moving forward. Not
sure what your schedule is like right now, but Bloc will pair you with
another mentor once I am out of the system. I hope you stick with Bloc
because it is a great program and there are certainly other great design
and front end mentors.

We haven’t connected in awhile, so please let me know how this impacts what
you do next and any  questions you have. I think they’ll disable my @bloc.io
email address, so please use this address.

Looking forward to hearing from you!

Matt

subject: Re: Ridgeline Fundraising Site
body:
Got it, thanks!

On Thu, Jul 20, 2017 at 6:09 PM Tyler Drewitz <tdrewitz@gmail.com> wrote:

> In case you don’t check that email.

> Begin forwarded message:

> *From: *Pastor Ryan Huguley <pastorryan@hickoryharvest.org>
> *Subject: **Ridgeline Fundraising Site*
> *Date: *July 20, 2017 at 6:45:10 PM EDT
> *To: *Matthew Born <matthewcyan@gmail.com>
> *Cc: *Tyler Drewitz <Tdrewitz@gmail.com>




> Hey Matt,
> Here is basic copy for the site. I think the important thing to keep in
> mind at this point is the purpose and audience of this site. It is NOT the
> church website. The purpose is to give potential supporters a very basic
> overview of where we’re headed and why. The audience is mainly going to be
> people who are already pretty on board and certain their going to support
> us, rather than a major mechanism for convincing them.

> I don’t have a strong version for how this lays out, but I do like Josh
> and Emily’s format (they’re the ones planting cross and anchor). It’s as
> simple as scrolling down. Totally open if you think there is a better and
> more simple way. Tyler can get you any links you may need.

> Lastly, for the short run, you think it would work to use the gold version
> of the logo, or no?

> Let me know and thank you!

> Ryan



> *Vision*
> To plant a church in pursuit of a spiritual awakening in the Salt Lake
> County.


> *Why Salt Lake City?*
> Salt Lake City is marked by equal parts beauty and darkness. Home to
> stunning mountain views, world-class recreation, and a booming business  
> and
> tech industry, it is also a city far from Jesus. Salt Lake City is home to
> the headquarters of the Church of Jesus Christ of Later Day Saints, as  
> well
> as a strong counter-culture with no interest in organized religion.

> The fifth fastest growing city in the U.S., Salt Lake City has over 2
> million people living in the metro area and is projected to double in
> coming years. Sadly, less than 3% of the population professes a
> life-changing, eternity altering relationship with Jesus Christ. Salt Lake
> is a vibrant, growing city in need of an ever-growing gospel-presence.

> *Our Story*
> Ryan and Tami met in 2001 while working at Starbucks together. They
> married in 2005 and now have three children - Ava, Ryder, and Lincoln, as
> well as a dog named Wicket (obviously named after the most famous Ewok  
> from
> "Return of the Jedi").

> After serving as a worship pastor for three years, Ryan and Tami planted
> Redemption Bible Church in 2009 in the suburbs of Chicago, where they
> served for seven years. In 2016, they packed up and moved to Hickory, NC
> where Ryan became the Senior Pastor of Harvest Bible Chapel. After fifteen
> months of service the church had grown by over 300 people and Ryan and  
> Tami
> began to sense a call to plant again.

> In the fall of 2018 the Huguley’s head out again for a new adventure - to
> plant Ridgeline Church in the Salt Lake City.

> View A Message Link

> Speaker Request

> *Get Involved*
> Pray.
> Pray for the Huguley’s, the team and Ridgeline Church. Join our mailing
> list here.

> Give.
> It takes resources to reach people. All of us together will have to
> contribute to see London reached for Jesus. Visit the link for secure
> giving, or mail a check to our sending church:

> Redemption Bible Church
> 350 W. Kensington Rd. Suite 106
> Mount Prospect, IL 60056

> Please make sure to include “Ridgeline Church” in the memo of your check.

> Go.
> It takes people to reach people. We need a team. Consider giving your life
> for 6 months, a year, or forever to see lives changed for eternity.

subject: Re: Weekly Update - 4 A.B.
body:
This is a fantastic update! Diligence and persistence is the only way to
guarantee a good result.

1. Are you still keeping track of your applications in the spreadsheet? I
did not see Powerfront in the list.

2. Well done on Dribbble! Already over 500 views and several comments. Keep
going and read this if you haven’t already:
https://blog.intercom.com/the-dribbblisation-of-design/

3. Please share the link to the site that is like Codewars.

4. WordPress is 3 very different things: configuration, content management,
and advanced capabilities. While it is helpful to be familiar with
WordPress, almost every organization doesn’t actually need any of these
things specifically from WordPress and most only really need help with
content management even though they think they need more. We can chat more
about this and I’ll try to help you filter out the noise.

5. Last big conference I went to was Google I/O last year. I try to avoid
design conferences because they sort of all turn into the same thing after
awhile. I attend, host, and speak at smaller events on a regular basis, but
that’s a lot easier to do in Chicago like we discussed before. Some of my
coworkers highly recommend valiocon.com, aneventapart.com, smashingconf.com,
and howdesignlive.com. Avoid any conferences that don’t have any
recognizable speakers because they are just trying to make money.
Definitely go to Dragoncon again this year, but treat it as an opportunity
to build your network and ask around about marketing needs. :)

Thanks for the thoughtful update! I’ll text you to see if you can still do
a call today.

On Thu, Apr 20, 2017 at 7:15 PM, Erin Johnson <erinjohnson21@gmail.com>
wrote:

> So I had an interview Tuesday for a remote graphic design job. It was for
> a company called Powerfront. I guess I'll hear back from them if I move to

> Sent out a few more job apps this week. I am trying to look at all my job

> track. I don't know if I should be doing anything differently. My cover
> letter probably does need some work though....

> I also uploaded a few things to dribbble this week at least to have a
> presence on there.

> Still trying to work on coding exercises. I found a new "codewars" type
> site but I got stuck after a couple problems. I just really suck at those
> but I probably need to keep doing them because if I don't there is no way
> I'll get better.
>
> Been working with Wordpress this week and trying to get at least some kind

>
> I guess that is all until tomorrow!
>
> Erin

subject: Re: hey hey
body:
This is great to hear! I am happy you feel confident and that things are
moving where you were hoping they would. Feel free to reach out to me with
anything whenever. A few questions for you:

1. Do I have your consent to share your personal site and projects to other
students and colleagues?

2. Are you cool with me bugging you about any questions Bloc has about your
employment and satisfaction with the program?

3. Are you interested in collaborating on any projects in the future? Beer
apps for fun? Nonprofit work for good? Freelance work for money?

It’s been such a pleasure working with you. Please don’t stop writing about
your progress. :)

🍻
—Matt

subject: Hey, Will & Ky! I am a designer from Chicago…
body:
Hey, Will & Ky!

I am a designer from Chicago eager to learn more about creative
opportunities in Charleston. My wife Megan and I are planning a move to the
area so we are researching to learn more about the community, the creative
culture, and places to live. I came across your site and shared it with Meg
right away since we both admire such a refined and minimal aesthetic.

Do you have any suggestions on where to look or who to contact?

I greatly appreciate your time!

Cheers,
Matt

subject: Panopta video project
body:
Hey Pat,

Ricky is one of the best designers I know, and can pretty much do anything
you throw at him. If he isn’t able to take on the project, he might be able
to find someone else.

Ricky, here are the initial details Pat shared with me:

> The company is panopta.com and they are looking to do explainer video for
the homepage banner. No real timeline just of yet but they would want a
video in the next month or so. Your top line earning potential could be
around $800 - $1,500 for doing the design work for storyboards and other
graphic elements needed for the video.  I would be doing the animation.

> The contact at the company is a personal friend of mine and is pretty
easy to work with but as you know sometimes things go crazy. I would be
doing all the client facing communication. If you think this is something
you would be interested in doing let me know and we can jump on a call and
catch up.

I’ll let you both take it from here.

Cheers!

subject: Re: Freelance designer
body:
Hey, Pat!

Good to hear from you. I picked up a single freelance job back in the fall,
and quickly got burnt out from the horrors of dealing with clients and
vendors. I am always willing to have a conversation, but I am highly
protective of my time and jaded enough to anticipate the worst on any
project.

Could you provide more details on the project(s) including who is involved,
what the timeline looks like, weekly time commitment, and top line earning
potential on my end?

Thanks!

On Sun, Feb 19, 2017 at 10:09 PM, Pat Reilly <preilly85@gmail.com> wrote:

> Hey Matt,
> I'm reaching out to see if your taking on any freelance jobs? I'm looking
> for some help with design for motion graphics and web site / landing page
> design.
>
> I may have some jobs coming up in the near future and looking for talented
> people to start collaborating with.  We had a few classes together back in
> the AI Schaumburg days and just stumbled on to your site. Hope everything
> is going well and looking forward on hearing back from you.
>
> Thanks,
> Pat Reilly
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Sent from my iPhone

subject: Refreeze?
body:
Hey Pete!

Just got the email that the 4 week freeze we set up has ended. Since we
only got to chat a couple times this month and your program only has 2
weeks left, I figure we should probably freeze at least another couple
weeks. Let me know if you agree and how many weeks (1-4).

Hope you are doing well!

Cheers

subject: Re: FW: UI Design for SaaS Start-up
body:
I think the project price is fair given the number of unique pages they
will be coding. That said, I’m having a tough time understanding what he
means by this paragraph:

*Please keep in mind that this is the most intensive, and time consuming
phase of both design and front-end development. I would strongly advise to
avoid making savings at this time, as the decisions we make here especially
regarding design, will be extremely costly to correct later (drastic
redesigns are expensive, annoy and alienate users, etc).*

This sounds like the opposite of how this typically works in the app world.
Until the market validates their design decisions, they are mostly guesses
and likely to change over time. Since they already know you intend to
continue working with them, I’m surprised they aren’t suggesting a more
iterative, conversion-driven approach that is lower fidelity and
faster-to-market.

My recommendation would be to go with “accent on speed” option and
encourage the “designing within the browser” workflow. If you are getting
regular updates on progress, you will be able to learn about how long
certain views are taking compared to others. I am curious to know how they
are spending their hours if you have already done the wireframes and they
aren’t going to be reworking against usability testing. It should be pretty
fast if they are only getting it in the browser using their existing style
conventions since you don’t have an established brand, yet.

As for development, I’m less concerned about setup as I am functional
value. If they are able to deliver all the functionality in the wireframe
for less than $10k, that sounds like a bargain by American standards.

Happy to keep talking through this to help you make decisions!

On Wed, Jan 4, 2017 at 11:24 PM, Peter Hood <peter@peterhood.com> wrote:

> Hi Matt,
>
>
>
> As per our IM chat, here is the last email in the thread.
>
>
>
> A few things about this:
>
> ·         It is for the SaaS framework/plumbing, as per my XD (PDF
> version of it attached)
>
> ·         They will present final design as static HTML/CSS and hand over
> to developer to implement into the application. Developer will do all
> Javascript coding (using AJAX & ReactJS where required)
>
> ·         I am treating the framework as Project 1, to make sure I am
> happy with both the designer and the developer and make sure it is going to
> work moving forward (and also to get an idea of costs)
>
> ·         As this is a do-and-charge arrangement, it will be $65 USD per
> hour. If it goes well, I can commit to 6 month contract and the rate
> reduces to $50 USD per hour
>
> ·         In future, they have suggested I just do specifications
> document, and perhaps a very basic wireframe, otherwise I would be doing a
> lot of their job etc.
>
>
>
> What are your thoughts on this?
>
>
>
> The developer has come in at about $7.7k for their part (includes setup of
> AWS/Server/CI/Build environments etc.). The developer will be on fixed fee.
>
>
>
> Cheers,
>
> Pete
>
>
>
> *From: *Dragan Babic <dragan@sprawsm.com>
> *Date: *Friday, 30 December 2016 at 11:35 PM
> *To: *Peter Hood <peter@peterhood.com>
> *Subject: *Re: UI Design for SaaS Start-up
>
>
>
> Hi Peter,
>
>
>
> thanks for clarifying that. I was thrown off by the terminology and wasn't
> sure what you meant by "SaaS framework". Design-Wise that means something
> completely different than what you were referencing.
>
>
>
> Here are the screens I have identified as deliverables:
>
>
>
> 1. Public holding page
>
> 2-3-4-5. Sign up, log in, reset password flow, full screen message
>
> 6. Sign up screen after accepting an invitation
>
> 7. Full screen welcome screen after successful signup
>
> 8. Profile form (I am assuming that the profile doesn't have a separate
> read-only view)
>
> 9. Flash messages: success, error, dialog
>
> 10. Account screens:
>
> 10.1. Details
>
> 10.2. Billing
>
> 10.3. Plan
>
> 10.4. Users, create new, edit existing flow
>
> 10.5. Groups, create new, edit existing flow
>
> 10.6. ConnectWise
>
>
>
> I am not taking the emails into consideration for this estimate, as they
> can be standard plain emails at least for the time being.
>
>
>
> Let me give you a couple of possible scenarios on how this can go:
>
>
>
> 1. Accent on speed
>
>
>
> We focus on delivering a "good enough" UI while saving up as much time,
> and thus budget as possible. Of course the UI will by no means be bad, it
> just means that we'll go with straight-forward solutions, instead of
> exploring other possible solutions.
>
>
>
> Time needed for design: two weeks.
>
>
>
> 2. Accent on quality.
>
>
>
> Focus on delivering UI through a design process that takes more
> possibilities into consideration while opting for a final solution to a
> design problem. Requires more time, and thus budget, but will yield better
> results.
>
>
>
> Time needed for design: three weeks.
>
>
>
> As for the front-end development, in both cases we think we'll need around
> two weeks in order to code everything up, do QA on the front-end, and
> establish a base for the UI framework that's to be used throughout the app.
>
>
>
> All these scenarios assume a single person working on the project full
> time, so assume 4-5 billable hours per day average in order to estimate the
> cost.
>
>
>
> Please keep in mind that this is the most intensive, and time consuming
> phase of both design and front-end development. I would strongly advise to
> avoid making savings at this time, as the decisions we make here especially
> regarding design, will be extremely costly to correct later (drastic
> redesigns are expensive, annoy and alienate users, etc).
>
>
>
> As for going forward after this, I think there's a tremendous opportunity
> to make savings by “designing within the browser” as we call it. Basically
> — and this is especially applicable to application UIs — we would skip the
> image-based mockup in a lot of cases and code the screens up using the
> available elements, and obviously creating new ones when needed. This is
> actually our preferred method of working on web apps.
>
>
>
> This is my honest, and realistic estimate for this job, and honestly the
> best I can do with the limited amount of knowledge I have about the product
> as a whole.
>
>
>
> Let me know what you decide, and should you decide to go forward with us I
> will prepare a contract we can sign on january 9th 2017 when we get back to
> the office. As soon as we have the contract signed, and you send me proof
> of payment for the 50% advance, we can start working.
>
>
>
> Cheers.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

subject: KBB progress update
body:
Morning, gents!

I am only half way through the admin changes, so that has not been migrated
to Jekyll, yet. Going to spend another hour on it now to try to get it into
Jekyll.

In other news, I merged Ricky’s most recent commit to master and that
redeployed successfully on CloudCannon which you can see here:
http://bubblegum-sunflower.cloudvent.net

To recap my short list of priorities:

[x] Update logic to support preview and save in admin
[ ] Update admin to match design (working on now)
[ ] Move code to admin route in Jekyll
[ ] Add script to update hard-coded widgets with values from Firebase
[x] CloudCannon debugging
[ ] Help Ricky with second level selection persistence unless he beats me
to it
[ ] Help Ricky with filters in SRP unless he beats me to it
[ ] Search

Will send another update as soon as the admin is migrated!

👍

subject: Re: bike helmets
body:
This is the article I read that pulls in data from various studies from the
past several decades:

http://www.howiechong.com/journal/2014/2/bike-helmets

To quote Thomas Piketty, “Without precisely defined sources, methods, and
concepts, it is possible to see everything and its opposite.” (from the
introduction of his book Capital in the 21st Century) While he is talking
about the distribution of wealth, I think this idea holds true even out of
context.

Matt

subject: Re: KBB Admin Tool - description
body:
Hey Pat,

Here is the static admin that confirms all of this will work. I saw some
errors in the console from brightcove which is coming from the iframes, but
I’m not sure what it is causing that, yet. Next steps will be to update
this to match your admin spec and wire up the price advisors and widgets in
Jekyll.

Username is your email, password is monkeyisabadpassword

http://bl.ocks.org/mattborn/293722333b5672bdf95b56d9f9b81de4

Only tested with the new vehicles so far, so nothing yet for the used
vehicles, but that should go fast since it’s all editable.

On Wed, Sep 21, 2016 at 9:15 AM, Pat Tomarchio <pat@logicartsstudios.com>
wrote:

> Here's the description:
>
> *Tier 3 Admin Tool*
>
> *Description*
>
> The Tier 3 Admin Tool will enable KBB to dynamically update the following
> Tier 3 web site vehicle information:
>
>    - *Live Price Advisors* for New and Pre-Owned vehicles - will feed the
>    SRP and VDP pages
>    - *Live Widgets* for New and Pre-Owned vehicles - will feed the VDP
>    pages
>
>
> ------
>
> *The Admin Tool Components:*
>
>
> *Sign-in Screen *KBB to provide Admin user names and their email addresses
>
>    - Admin users will enter their email and password to enter the Admin
>    Tool
>
>
>
> * Select Vehicle *
>
>    - Select vehicle to updated from New and Pre-Owned list
>
>
>
> *Vehicle Data Page *The Vehicle Data Page has 3 sections, each with
> specific data fields used to update vehicle information:
>
>    1. Price Advisor - feeds the SRP and VDP pages
>    2. Pricing Stack - feeds the SRP and VDP pages
>    3. Widgets - feeds the VDP pages
>
>
> ------
>
> *Vehicle Data Page - Sections and Data Fields*
>
> *1. Price Advisor section*
>
>    - Zip Code - *enter data here*
>    - Vehicle ID#  - *enter data here*
>    - Dealer Sale Price (*listed as AskingPrice on KBB Toolkit site*) - *enter
>    data here*
>
>
> A Price Advisor is generated in an iFrame. The Admin can see the Price
> Advisor pricing values to use in the Pricing Stack section.
>
> --
>
> *2a. New Vehicle Pricing Stack section*
>
>    - MRSP - *enter data here*
>    - Discount - *automatically calculated*
>    - Dealer Sale Price - *automatically entered from Price Advisor entry
>    above*
>    - Factory Rebate - *enter data here*
>    - New Price - *automatically calculated*
>
>
>
> *Example: New Vehicle Price Stack is generated: *
> MSRP                       $27,880
> Dealer Discount       -$1,425
> Dealer Sale Price      $26,455
> Factory Rebate         -$2,450
> Net Price                  $24,005
>
> --
>
> *2b. (or) Pre-Owned Vehicle Pricing Stack section*
>
>    - Pre-Owned Price - *enter data here*
>
>
>
> *Example: Pre-Owned Price Stack is generated: *
> Price                       $18,590
>
> --
>
>
> *3. Widget section *The Widget section has a separate Vehicle ID# to give
> KBB the flexibility to enter different values from the Price Advisor in the
> event a new-year vehicle model does not have Expert or Consumer review data
> yet for example.
>
>
>    - Vehicle ID#  - *enter data here*
>
>
> ------
>
> *KBB Price Advisor and Widget Toolkit web sites to generate **KBB Data
> Source Code*
>
> Using the KBB ToolKit web sites, we will generate generic html code string
> for:
>
>    - New Price Advisor
>    - Pre-Owned Price Advisor
>    - Consumer Ratings and Reviews
>    - Expert Ratings and Reviews
>    - (Awards are not included in the Admin Tool functionality.)
>
>
> *Generating the Code*
>
> The Admin Tool will insert the entered data into the html code string
> provided by the KBB Toolikit web sites (as described in the *Sections and
> Data Fields*). This data entered will be inserted into the hard-coded
> html code strings by the Admin Tool. The Admin Tool will not in any way
> dynamically link to the KBB Toolkit web sites.
>
> Example iFrame code generated from the KBB Toolkit site:
>
>
> *<iframe width="300" height="375" frameBorder="0" scrolling="no"
> style="border:0px none #FFFFFF"
> src="//panc.syndication.kbb.com/priceadvisornewcar/fairpurchaseprice?APIKey=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000&ZipCode=&VehicleId=&DisplayMSRP=true&DisplayAskingPrice=true&DisplayFPP=false
> <http://panc.syndication.kbb.com/priceadvisornewcar/fairpurchaseprice?APIKey=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000&ZipCode=&VehicleId=&DisplayMSRP=true&DisplayAskingPrice=true&DisplayFPP=false>"
> ></iframe> *
> KBB will provide Upper Diamond with the API key to generate the necessary
> html strings for each product and vehicle.
>
> ---
>
> *Toolkit websites provided by KBB*
>
> Price Advisor
>
>    - http://panc.syndication.kbb.com/PriceAdvisorNewCar
>    - http://pauc.syndication.kbb.com/PriceAdvisorUsedCar
>
>
> Editorial Widgets
>
>    - http://rrc.syndication.kbb.com/RatingsAndReviewsConsumer/Help
>    - http://rre.syndication.kbb.com/RatingsAndReviewsExpert/Help
>    - http://aa.syndication.kbb.com/AwardsAndAccolades/Help
>
>
> --
>

> Logic Arts Studios | A Digital Agency
>

> (310) 384-8480  Mobile
> (866) 514-7722  Fax
> 10061 Riverside Drive, #765

body:
Morning guys,

Scaffolded the GitHub repo with a fresh Jekyll instance including
placeholder files and templates for most of the project. Hopefully, this
will save Ricky some time and allow him to focus on the details of each of
the static pages. I included my notes on most of the outstanding work in
the README.md file in that repo. I also coded some low hanging fruit like
the Google map, but we’ll need to swap the API key since it’s using mine.
I’m sure more details will come out of your meeting, but be sure to take a
look at it when you get a chance. Ricky, we’ll need to add you to that repo
today.

Let me know if you have any questions. Otherwise, I’ll plan on making
myself available around 11 to answer any questions about the repo.

Cheers!
