subject: Notes from JMac sermon today
body:
## Prayer something

1. Pattern - Confession Adoration Thanksgiving Supplication
2. Plan - alone, kneel, posture of humility (interlock hands), pray out
loud, with a list, pattern
3. Partner - the hardest moment in prayer is the first moment
4. Pace
5. Particulars - if prodigal, pray for the day of trouble; if discouraged,
pray for one of God’s promises to be especially true for today

## 1a) Pray for emotional health

- James 5:13 - A rhetorical question is where the answer is obvious. Is
anyone among you suffering? Is anyone cheerful?
- Suffering translation = enduring evil treatment from people.
- Present imperative, Let him pray / sing praise.
- Cheerful translation = A positive, hopeful outlook.

**In suffering and celebration, your choice to pray and praise has
immediate and lasting rewards in your emotional health.**

- You’re connecting that to…, and it will be rewarded.

- It will be rewarded with relief
- If you are suffering and you pray, if you’re…
- If it’s a burden, it will be gone. You will experience peace.

1. Relief - burden left
2. Peace - burden lifted
3. Joy - burden answered
4. Faith - re: future burdens
5. Confidence - re: unknown burdens

Acts 16?

1. Tell God how you feel - we tell God what’s happening because He wants to
know that we know that He knows
2. Ask Him to search your heart for why - is it unresolved sin, does my
heart need to change?
3. Turn your thoughts towards God - count your blessings,
4. Read a song of praise and thanksgiving

[I tried to answer my own prayer.] If you’re going to leave it with God,
leave it with God.

## 2a) Pray for physical health

- Sick person makes the call
- We believe in a plurality of elders, elders is plural there and I think
that’s important
- Their purpose for going is not to anoint with oil, their purpose for
going is not to heal, their purpose for going is to pray.

Anointing with oil?
- Medicinal? No.
- Figurative? No.
- Symbolic? Yes, of the Holy Spirit. Symbols matter. We don’t have a lot of
symbols. Cross. Pulpit (centrality of God’s word).

All prayer is a prayer of faith. There will be a result from it.

Biblical purposes for sickness

All sickness is not from sin

1. To glorify God - John 9:2–3
2. To teach humility - 2 Corinthians 12:7–10
3. To refine our character - Job 23:10
4. To convict about gross sin - 1 Corinthians 11:27–30

in some self-flatulation of sin… that we will delight in grace?

4 points on healing

1. God does not make us sick or give disease except as a consequence of sin
2. God does use every hardship we face for our Good
3. God does heal people to bring glory to His name, to relieve a trial that
is too heavy
4. ?

## 3a) Pray for spiritual health

It doesn’t have to be some incantation, we are not convincing God, He is
already willing.

subject: Re: Beer soon?
body:
Hey, Tom. Sorry to leave you hanging. I’ve been under a lot of pressure
lately and I am behind on a lot of stuff. Please don’t take it personally.
Meeting in person is exceptionally difficult and I have a few other people
I’ve been stringing along as well. Let’s start with a scheduled phone call
if that works for you. I am going to text you from my mobile. Hope you have
been doing well! Talk soon.

subject: Freelance web development for Logic Arts Studios
body:
Hey Ricky!

I have copied Pat on this email as a virtual handshake between the two of
you. Pat runs a dev shop out of LA and they have a project ready for
development.

Their original plan was to use WordPress, but since there is only a small
part of the site that needs to be configurable by the client and Pat’s team
is capable of editing the content between HTML tags, I suggested we find
someone to code this out statically. That’s where you come in.

Pat has a template-based prototype with complete visual design that was
already approved by the client. My initial estimate was around 60 hours
using Jekyll to generate static pages from custom templates and a small
custom admin form using Firebase that can ship with the static assets.

I can help with the custom admin and I will seed the Jekyll repo on GitHub
for you so you can focus on coding out all the static content and making
sure everything works on mobile, tablet, and desktop. Pat and I both have
some notes to share, but mine aren’t ready, yet so I’ll try to have those
later this evening.

The planned start date is this coming Monday, September 19 based on your
availability. Pat needs your quote and ship date as soon as you have time
to take a look at the project. I am happy to run through it with you
whenever you are free, but I’m sure Pat will be able to answer more
questions.

Just going to send this to get the conversation started. Either Pat or
myself will share links and more details soon.

Looking forward to working together!

Matt

subject: Re: Slideshow template for iA Writer
body:
Just found this in my spam folder due to the unrecognized attachment. Will
install and get back to you. Thanks!

On Fri, Sep 9, 2016 at 3:34 AM, Iain Humm <ih@ia.net> wrote:

> Hello and thanks again for volunteering to test iA's new Slideshow
> template for iA Writer.
>
> This latest update improves on the previous with better sized headings,
> superior image handling and PDF export. It is also now possible to swipe
> between slides using a mouse wheel or trackpad.
>
> A reminder: The Preview must be in focus for slides to change, so ensure
> you've clicked somewhere on the Preview pane before navigating slides.
>
> # Installation
> To install the template, unpack the attached zip and double-click on the
> bundle. On iOS, you can choose "Open in…" and then "Copy to iA Writer". No
> need to extract the zip beforehand.
>
> # Use
> - Separate slides with three hyphens, as you would normally add a
> horizontal rule.
> - Adding or deleting any text will shift the Preview to the slide being
> edited
> - With the Preview in focus use ← or → to change slides (you can also use
> ↑ and ↓ or the space bar to go one by one)
> - Use Esc for an overview, or type ? for a quick reference of keyboard
> shortcuts
> - On iOS, swipe between slides and pinch for an overview
>
> # More info
> The template is based uses reveal.js, so you can learn more about the
> inner-workings on its GitHub page.
>
> After playing with the template for a bit, please let me know if you
> encounter any serious issues, and your experience as a whole.
>
> Kind regards,
> Iain Humm
>
>
> –
> Information Architects
> Tokyo
>
> https://ia.net
>
>
>

subject: Storms make trees take deeper roots
body:
Negative defining statements:

## Last night

1. “You should cut your hair like David Boudia.”
2. [criticized for having sex the previous night]

## This morning

3. “You still haven’t put up the curtains. I have been asking you for 14
months.”
4. “Yes, you should shave. I like seeing your face better.”
5. “What are we doing for our anniversary?” · Unspoken context: I know you
haven’t made plans for our anniversary, yet.
6. “We should take Maely to my parents and go to St. Louis.” · Unspoken
context: You don’t do enough fun things for me like Eric does for Sabriah

## During fight

7. “You aren’t a loving dictator, and you are only spiritual when you need
to [make a point].” (paraphrase)
8. “You aren’t fun anymore.” · Unspoken context: You need to change because
I want to be with someone who is fun.
9. “I want to leave right now, and you obviously aren’t coming.” · Unspoken
context: You are the one who is keeping us from going to church, and I am
better than you for being ready to go.
10. “You are insecure.” · Unspoken context: I am not.
11. “All you do is complain and I don’t want to be around that.”

---

My complaint is that you rarely admit when you are cruel or verbally
abusive. I have other minor complaints (money, work, etc.), but nothing
comes close in weight to this. I am stubborn. I am outspoken. I am brazen
to a fault, but I am not cruel.

cruel - willfully causing pain or suffering to others, or feeling no
concern about it.

---

Verbal abuse is described as a negative defining statement told to the
victim or about the victim, or *by withholding any response, thereby
defining the target as non-existent*. If the abuser does not immediately
apologize and retract the defining statement, the relationship may be a
verbally abusive one.

In couple relationships, the verbal abuser responds to the partner's
"separateness," i.e., independent thoughts, views, desires, feelings,
expressions (even of happiness) as an irritant or even an attack. While
some people believe the abuser has low self-esteem and so attempts to place
their victim in a similar position, i.e., to believe negative things about
themselves, this is not usually the case in couple relationships. One
partner may, for example, disparage the other simply because that one
partner has qualities that were disparaged, e.g., emotional intelligence,
warmth, receptivity, and so forth.

Anyone can experience verbal abuse. Typically, in couple or family
relationships, verbal abuse increases in intensity and frequency over time.
After exposure to verbal abuse, victims may develop clinical depression
and/or post-traumatic stress disorder. The person targeted by verbal abuse
over time may succumb to any stress related illness. Verbal abuse creates
emotional pain and mental anguish in its target.

---

I know you think I am the one who verbally abuses you, but I think I am
responding to your negative defining statements in a state of mental
anguish which is typically aggressive and hasty. We need to deal with this
together responsibly. My recommendation is to see a counselor, but you
should also be able to speak to me openly and honestly about this.

Maely needs us to keep growing. By ignoring this, we have been stagnant in
our sanctification.

I love you so deeply. Always.

accepted another offer. Happy to have a conversation.

Matt

wrote:

> Hey Matt,
>
> I'm the Director of Product at eSpark Learning (esparklearning.com), an
> educational tech company in Chicago. We're looking for someone awesome for
> this new product designer
> <https://boards.greenhouse.io/esparklearning/jobs/220084?gh_jid=220084#.V4fv5ZMrKHo>

>

subject: Fwd: Bloc Program
body:
She wants to know if she is “complete in the eyes of Bloc.”

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Kayli Hamilton <hamilton.kayli@gmail.com>
Date: Fri, Jun 17, 2016 at 6:58 PM
Subject: Bloc Program
To: Matt Born <me@mattborn.com>


Hi Matt,

I am reaching out because I have a question regarding the remainder of our
program.  I know that I was initially scheduled to be complete June 20, and
my time was extended to July 17.  Which I still don't understand.

I have completed the requirements for both the ruby/rails, front end, and
the portfolio.  Does that mean I am technically complete to where Bloc
views me as successfully completing the full stack web developer program??

Is the career prep required?? I know I mentioned I was seeking employment
post Bloc, but given the lack of Bloc connection with employers in my area
and Bloc not wanting to stake their reputation on reaching out to employers
on my behalf because my first mock interview did not go well.  I would like
to be complete with Bloc and continue my employment search independently.
I have already started applying and reaching out to employers and have
received positive feedback.

Please let me know if Bloc views my status as having  completed The Full
Stack Web Developer Track at this point.

Thank you Matt for your time,
Kayli Hamilton

subject: Re: Bloc Program
body:
Morning, Kayli!

I’m confident in your abilities, and I want to do whatever you think is
best.

Would you mind if I forwarded this to my lead mentor, Levi? This would be a
first for me, so I’d like his input.

On Fri, Jun 17, 2016 at 6:58 PM, Kayli Hamilton <hamilton.kayli@gmail.com>
wrote:

> Hi Matt,
>
> I am reaching out because I have a question regarding the remainder of our
> program.  I know that I was initially scheduled to be complete June 20, and
> my time was extended to July 17.  Which I still don't understand.
>
> I have completed the requirements for both the ruby/rails, front end, and
> the portfolio.  Does that mean I am technically complete to where Bloc
> views me as successfully completing the full stack web developer program??
>
> Is the career prep required?? I know I mentioned I was seeking employment
> post Bloc, but given the lack of Bloc connection with employers in my area
> and Bloc not wanting to stake their reputation on reaching out to employers
> on my behalf because my first mock interview did not go well.  I would like
> to be complete with Bloc and continue my employment search independently.
> I have already started applying and reaching out to employers and have
> received positive feedback.
>
> Please let me know if Bloc views my status as having  completed The Full
> Stack Web Developer Track at this point.
>
> Thank you Matt for your time,
> Kayli Hamilton
>

subject: Re: Notes from our conversation
body:
Will!

How is it June already? I am sad that I probably missed the conference that
was planned for Rockford. Work has been very demanding these past few
months, but I am still very eager to get involved. I just had a couple
students graduate, so I have a few extra hours the next couple weeks that I
plan to use to work on those visuals I promised you months ago.

Anyways, I hope things are going well for you and the organization. I am
interested to hear about your dissertation. Talk to you again soon.

Cheers,
Matt

On Tue, Feb 9, 2016 at 9:17 PM, Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:

> Thanks again for taking the time to speak with me! I really enjoyed our
> conversation and I feel I have a much better understanding of the state of
> things.
>
> I added my notes here on all the things we discussed for your reference
> and mine:
>
> https://gist.github.com/mattborn/5a01d7ba84e60759ae3c
>
> This is a private link that won’t be indexed and is only available to
> those with the link.
>
> I’ll be sure to follow up with you regarding the next board meeting.
>
> In the meantime, I’ll begin putting some visuals together.
>
> Cheers!
>

subject: Re: Help feed the world with The Climate Corporation!
body:
A very interesting proposal indeed, Annette. What is the rank of the
position, salary range, equity, and benefits? Also, would I be able to work
remotely some or most of the time?

On Wed, Jun 1, 2016 at 5:57 PM, Annette Sarlatte <
annette.sarlatte-matsu@climate.com> wrote:

> Hi Matt,
>
> My name is Annette, and I am helping to build out the Product & Design
> teams here at The Climate Corporation.
>
> We're looking for a highly qualified designer in our Chicago office like
> yourself to help us build native mobile apps that help farmers turn data
> into insights, improve their yield, and ultimately feed the world.
>
> If you like to build products that have real-world impact and meaning and
> that look beautiful and intuitive (I can already see from your LI profile
> that you, like most of us here, are well-versed in cocktail parties and
> hair care), let me know when you're free for a quick chat some time this
> week or next; I think we could potentially be a great match for you and
> your considerable skills!
>
> Have a great rest of your day!
>
> Best,
> Annette
>

subject: Re: Building Chicago's next unicorn / Raise.com
body:
Hey Pete,

I met some Raise folks at Techweek either last year or the year before, but
other than that I don’t know much about your company. My schedule is
constantly changing as I have some students I mentor graduating and new
ones starting, but I should be able to do an early morning in the next
couple weeks. All my lunch hours are currently booked for the next few
weeks and work schedule is very tight. I have a 7:30-8am open this Tuesday
the 31st or next Monday the 6th same time. I typically do morning meetings
at Kingsbaker Cafe in the West Loop. Do either of these work for you?

Cheers,
Matt

subject: Re: job negotitation
body:
Love that you are being direct. Send it!

On Mon, May 2, 2016 at 8:14 PM, Tyler Schmidt <tylernelsonschmidt@gmail.com>
wrote:

> Hey man, I wanted to send over a draft of my response to built in to get
> your thoughts first if you don't mind
>
> ------
>
> Hi Maria and Aaron
>
> I wanted to thank you again for your offer, but in the interest of
> transparency, it was lower than I expected.
>
> At my current contract to hire role at Enova, I am making the equivalent
> of 52k annual salary and when I am moved to a salaried role I would receive
> similar benefits as those offered at Built In.
>
> I feel that in making a move to a different company I should be making a
> move in salary as well, and I think something closer to (insert number here
> i think 60k or so) is more fair given my current compensation, and the
> average salary for a product designer in Chicago.
>
> Please let me know your thoughts,
>
> Tyler
>
> -----------
>
> basically i think it doesn't make sense to take such a severe paycut for
> more hours and more responsibility along with the risks involved with start
> ups, so unless they are an upward movement I'm not sure if I should take
> it. Do you think i should add or get rid of anything?
>

subject: Re: Question For You
body:
Hey Mike,

There may be a conflict of interest here as I already work for a Lightbank
company. I am always willing to have a conversation, but the numbers have
to be right or everyone’s time is wasted. If you can get me $150k base,
substantial equity, full medical, and the option to work remote, let’s
talk. I also don’t currently have any friends who are either qualified or
looking for this.

Cheers!

> need for a senior product focused designer. This company is doing some

>> Hi Matt,
>>
>> I'm working with brand new startup called Tempus, who is applying big
>> data and analytics to bioinformatics for the sole purpose of improving
>> cancer research and treatment. We now have more data than ever before on
>> genomic sequencing, but providers don't have the infrastructure or
>> expertise to make sense of the data. Tempus is creating infrastructure to
>> house and analyze genomic data with the goal of partnering with hospitals
>> and large healthcare companies to help them create different approaches to
>> treating cancer by sequencing patients. The cancer research industry as a
>> whole has been virtually untouched for the last 50 years, so this is a
>> brand new greenfield opportunity right here in Chicago that was recently
>> backed by Lightbank.
>>
>> I'm reaching out to you because they are hiring across the board and they
>> desperately need product-focused designers as they are on the precipice or
>> rolling out their first product iteration. This would be a chance to come
>> in on the ground floor of a tremendous opportunity.

subject: Re: interviewss
body:
Rough night with the baby in strange environment, but the weather is very
good. :)

I promise you there are much more awkward conversations in your future.
Enova should respect your intentionality and be glad they didn’t waste a
couple weeks of training and assimilation on you. Tell Steelseries what you
told me. You accepted an offer at Enova through a connection at Bloc, but
you feel your passion aligns more with Steelseries and you believe you
would be much more connected to your work there. It could go either way,
but don’t be afraid. My optimism says that translates to you being wanted
as opposed to desperate, which is good.

Good luck! Let me know how it goes.

On Fri, Mar 11, 2016 at 7:01 AM, Tyler Schmidt <tylernelsonschmidt@gmail.com
> wrote:

> Hey man,
>
> hope your vacation is going good, I just wanted to throw a quick question
> your way if you have the time.
>
> So good news is, Im going in for an interview today at 3. My only real
> worry (aside from the potentially really awkward convo of quitting a new
> job on day 3) Im not sure how I should put my current work situation if
> they ask what i'm doing now. Obviously I don't want to lie to them, but at
> the same time I think it would be a bad idea to say I'm starting a new job
> on monday.
>
> Any ideas?
>
> --
> Tyler Schmidt
>
> www.tylernelsonschmidt.com
> http://society6.com/TylerSchmidt
>

do 7:30-8am for our appointments? That is the only availability I have now
since another new student just started and took both my lunch spots. If you
can make that work, I have time for you up to 3 appointments per week
depending on which pacing you want.

Let me know!

subject: Your program will resume on Sunday, February 14
body:
Hi Winnie,

Your Bloc program will be starting again soon!

On your return date, you'll receive an email with a link to
schedule your weekly appointments. Your account will be unfrozen,
and your program will resume.

We're happy to have you back!

Team Bloc

Copyright © 2016 Bloc. All rights reserved.

This email is a notification sent through Bloc.io.

For assistance, contact
help@bloc.io. ( mailto:help@bloc.io. )

subject: Notes from our conversation
body:
Thanks again for taking the time to speak with me! I really enjoyed our
conversation and I feel I have a much better understanding of the state of
things.

I added my notes here on all the things we discussed for your reference and
mine:

https://gist.github.com/mattborn/5a01d7ba84e60759ae3c

This is a private link that won’t be indexed and is only available to those
with the link.

I’ll be sure to follow up with you regarding the next board meeting.

In the meantime, I’ll begin putting some visuals together.

Cheers!

subject: Re: Thank you
body:
You owe me nothing, but let's have a beer to celebrate when you land a job.

Also, I realized as I left we never talked about compensation. While it is  
difficult to bargain without a salary history, I want to make sure you know  
where the numbers come from and how to protect yourself from getting locked  
into an underpaid position for many years. I say this both from experience  
and from close friends of mine who have been taken advantage of. I'll send  
you a write-up as soon as I can.

Good luck again! Let me know if you don't have an attractive offer on the  
table in the next few weeks.

Matt

PS Put in a good word with PJ at Gravity Tank. No promises, but they are  
looking for juniors, so if you don't get a follow-up, I'd reach out to ask  
what you could do to be a desirable candidate in the future.



On Fri, Feb 5, 2016 at 9:57 AM Tyler Schmidt <tylernelsonschmidt@gmail.com>  
wrote:


Hey Matt,



I wanted to say thanks again for meeting with me yesterday. I really  
appreciate all the good advice for not only my portfolio, but for job  
search and beyond. The insights to my portfolio and how to present myself  
is really invaluable and including my process for creatives that will see  
my work is a really great idea.



I owe you a beer!



--


Tyler Schmidt


www.tylernelsonschmidt.com
http://society6.com/TylerSchmidt

subject: Re: Volunteer for graphic design or web development
body:
Hello, Will!

Hope your week went well. I’ll have to say, Weebly is a much better
platform than I thought. I like the template you started because the
navigation seems much cleaner and more organized this way. I am interested
in gaining a better understanding of the specific goals of the site when it
comes to the following:

- Conversions (funding, newsletter, event signups, etc. including analytics
to measure all these independently)
- Improving the organization and presentation of original or curated
information and resources (research, tools, key influencers + policy
makers, petitions, etc.)
- Improving the existing brand (consistency, overall strength, downloadable
assets, on-message social sharing, etc.)

Would you have time to have a quick phone call about the state of these
things so I can grab some notes? In the meantime, I’ll start sifting
through content based on the hierarchy in your template to put some
recommendations together.

Thank you!

Matt
847 347 4463

Thanks again!


Cheers.



On Mon, Nov 30, 2015 at 9:56 PM, tammy <tammy@ilvoices.com> wrote:


Hi Matt!


I'm so glad to see that our recruiting efforts are paying off. We are  
trying to reach every registered citizen in Illinois. I'm going to forward  
this email to our Board Director, Will Mingus. He's been taking care of  
that part of IL Voices. If you don't hear back from him within a week, let  
me know.


So glad you signed up!


Tammy

Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change  
the world.
Indeed, it's the only thing that ever has. ~Margaret Mead


On November 29, 2015 at 10:42 PM Matt Born <me@mattborn.com> wrote:


Hello, Tammy!


I just signed up for the mailing list after receiving a letter in the mail.  
Could you send me more information on how I might get involved to help out  
with any visual design and/or coding needs?


Thank you!


Matt

body:

it to a spreadsheet here:

>>>>
>>>> For informational sites + marketing sites however, I now recommend
>>>> using free static hosting (like Github Pages), a very simple CMS that will

subject: Re: Volunteer for graphic design or web development
body:
Oh, I understand. Any effort would be purely academic as a way for me to
better understand the types of problems the site has so I can have more
informed conversations with you or the board about how I might be able to
help. As one of my former bosses used to say, “fast, cheap, good … pick
two.” Since this would be a volunteer effort on my part, the only thing
standing in the way of a good redesign is time.

subject: Re: Volunteer for graphic design or web development
body:
In the past, I have worked with everything from shtml and perl to php and
ruby. I worked as a WordPress dev for 2 years, then as a Rails developer
for another 2 years. Today, I prefer Javascript on the client and server
with Node.js for application development.

For informational sites + marketing sites however, I now recommend using
free static hosting (like Github Pages), a very simple CMS that will
generate pages for you (Prose.io or CloudCannon), and third party
integrations for everything else—Facebook Comments, Formspree for Contact
Forms, Typeform for complex forms, TinyLetter for newsletters, etc.

Note: CloudCannon is not free, but they have an awesome page showing all
the great tools out there that help keep costs down while providing a ton
of functionality:
http://cloudcannon.com/tips/2014/12/12/the-ultimate-list-of-services-for-static-websites.html

I’d be happy to scrape and convert all the public content on the current
ilvoices.com to show you an example of what I am talking about.

subject: Re: Volunteer for graphic design or web development
body:
Hello again, Will!

Sorry to leave you hanging there. I started a new part-time job right after
the holiday so I haven’t had as much free time lately.

I’ve been building websites for 17 years now and working professionally as
a web developer for over a decade. I also have a BFA in graphic design from
the Illinois Institute of Art. My current full time job is with a company
called Sprout Social where I am the lead product designer for our younger
product called Bambu (getbambu.com). I’ve been an online programming mentor
for the past 2 years, and I just joined Bloc.io as part-time employee. You
can see my Bloc mentor bio here: https://www.bloc.io/mentors/matt-born

I live in West Loop, Chicago with my wife Megan who is an interior designer
(meganborn.com) and my daughter Maely. For over 6 years, my wife and I have
been doing doing volunteer design work for our church in Arlington Heights
called Redemption Bible Church, so we have a lot of experience is this sort
of arrangement. The mission of Illinois Voices is important to both of us
as we have had our fair share of bumps in the road as a result of my
conviction and I want to make sure we are doing our part to try to make
things get better as my daughter gets older.

Like many web developers, it has been tricky to keep my portfolio and work
samples up to date, but I’ll leave you with a link to my last attempt:

http://bl.ocks.org/mattborn/raw/e75e409e5efadb1e3243

Let me know if there is anything I can take off your plate as a trial run.

Cheers!
Matt

subject: TinyLetter
body:
I couldn’t find your the .eps logo on my Google Drive, so it must be on one
of my external drives which means I’ll need to find some time to search for
it. However, I did find that email service I was talking about:

http://tinyletter.com

It’s a free service owned by MailChimp. Check it out and let me know what
you think!

Matt

subject: Joe, meet Jason (re: Berkshire Boston WordPress site)
body:
Hey Joe,

Jason is a WordPress expert. I already sent along the details of the
project you are looking to handoff, but I’ll include them again for clarity:

--

Hey guys. I’m looking to move a project off of my company and onto a
freelancer. It’s a WordPress site build for a newspaper in Massachusetts.
Good chunk of the work is already done.

Development site: http://berkshire.telegraphicsinc.com/

Remaining tasks includes:
• Content Transfer (importer already built)
• Ad System Setup (broadstreetads.com)
• Calendar area (linking up events + categories)
• Editorial Area Updates
• Some QA Testing
• A bunch of other random stuff they’ll probably come up with

We were going to try and finish the site for an additional $12k — which,
they agreed to. BUT, I think they’d be better off working with an
independent developer to have more of a one-on-one relationship for the
things they want to do.

My guess is you can charge hourly, probably up to $10k, at least. Which,
there shouldn’t be THAT much left to do. If you guys are, or if you think
someone might be able to handle it, I’d appreciate it.

--

Hope it works out!

Cheers,
Matt

subject: Re: Job App Grind
body:
Hello Alberto!

Sorry to hear that. I love your portfolio and think it’s more than up to snuff. As I’ve mentioned before, the front door is tough. Since you’ve been at this awhile now, I’d say it’s time to allow a recruiter to get you placed into regular interviews. They make money on your back, but at this point, it would be better for you to start getting interview experience anyways. The good news is, New York has the most tech jobs available. I’m not familiar with the better staffing agencies in NYC, but you could try some of these:

https://vitamintalent.com/find-work (a division of https://aquent.com)
http://52ltd.com
http://www.the80twenty.com
http://www.jobspringpartners.com/tech-jobs/new-york
http://www.workbridgeassociates.com (Same company as Jobspring)

You should also go to this event: http://www.meetup.com/techinmotionnyc/events/224406969/

The idea here is to have a person advocating for you around the clock until you’ve been placed. Be specific about the position you are looking for. It’s okay to have more than one agent, but things can get hectic really fast. I worked with Jobspring here in Chicago and my agent (one person) had me in a dozen in-person interviews in the first 2 weeks.

Let me know when you’ve found an agent you like working with.

Good luck!

-- 
Matt Born
Sent with Airmail

On September 24, 2015 at 9:09:16 AM, Alberto Guillermo de la Cruz (agdelax@gmail.com) wrote:

Hi Matt,

I was hoping to get some advice. I've sent maybe 30 job applications so far, some reaches but most were Junior Designer roles or even internships that I meet the requirements for. Thing is, I haven't heard back from any place that I've applied to, which is a little disheartening. I did receive a rejection letter from Percolate saying I'm not what they're looking for despite meeting their candidate criteria, but I was thankful just to have even received a response. 

I was wondering if there was anything wrong with my approach. I'm attaching my resume and a sample cover letter, having taken your advice in trying communicate more about why I'd like to apply at said company. It could also be my portfolio isn't up to snuff. I'm going to a startup job fair tomorrow, so hopefully I'll have a little more success there since I'd be meeting people in person. 

Cheers,
Alberto

subject: Question about Postmates’ background checks
body:
Hello Fleet Growth Team!

My name is Matt and I just had my onboarding session in Chicago yesterday.

I wanted to reach out to you guys regarding my background check because I do have a felony on my record. This offense occurred 6 years ago and I have completed all the requirements of my probation, but I’m sure this will come up during your check. I have had no problem finding and landing jobs since then with the exception of the Chicago Sun Times which was understandable given they are a major media outlet. My question to you guys then is which types of offenses and circumstances would lead to someone being ineligible to work for Postmates?

I’d be happy to answer any questions and share more details about my offense, but I figure it’s better to give you guys a heads up to avoid any surprises.

Thank you for your time! I’ll be looking forward to your response. Also, I would appreciate your discretion when forwarding / escalating this email.

Cheers.

-- 
Matt Born
Sent with Airmail
